column10: Please someone for the love of god, REMASTER this game already.

Hearkens back to the golden era of strategy games.  It is original in its implementation of squad reinforcement, fantastic battle animations and finishing moves,  exciting game play that will have players laughing maniacally at your overwhelming power or crying in frustration in the amount of ownership being dished out.

There are quite a few mods for that are available for this title as well however the player can run into inevitable stability issues with the use of these mods.  The core game play is solid without mods.

The absolute PEAK of RTS Games (Right up there with AoE) and - in my Opinion - Dawn of War games for this series.
Why in DoW's II & III they shifted the entire style of the game is beyond me as I very much despise RTS games that are super restrictive in what you can build/train, along with practically hand holding you throughout the entire campaign regardless of difficulty.

THIS though - this type of RTS that DoW I through Soulstorm - is what makes the perfect kind of RTS: Base Construction, Army building, countering, deployment tactics... that creative freedom is what makes the perfect RTS, in my opinion.
Soulstorm will always have a special place in my heart, and I enjoy revisiting it every now and then even if it's just a single quick Skirmish match.
I do hope that the dev's change the series back to this RTS style later on down the line.

I have a lot of fond memories about this game. Playing it as a lil kid, I remember fondly sowing terror and despair as the forces of chaos, or the inevitable, deathly onslaught of the Necrons. Of bodily charging into danger as the Blood Ravens, or holding the line in valiant defiance as the Imperial Guard. 
But most of all I remember my good friends, Tang (who owns a lovely restaurant these days who serve the most delightful salt and pepper chips) and Diego. We met in the summer of 2014, bright eyed young lads looking to make it big or die trying, and we happened upon a shared love of toy army men. So it was we became bound, bound to each other, and strangely to this game.
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War - Soulstorm, is decried by many, for its plethora of issues. Bizarre balance, barely functional flying units, batshit insane voice acting, equally maniacal plot, but beloved for its sheer, unbridled charm. Me, Tang and Diego fell in love with that charm. 
Many an evening was spent assailing Diego in his lair behind legions of Ork Boyz and waaagh banners, many a hour spent hunting down his last surviving "refugee" builder unit, many a minute cursing Tang's betrayal, or cheering on at my own triumph. 
Diego especially was something of a menace. A known poor sport, he would squirrel away builders, construct bases, and refuse to surrender even when clearly defeated. When he was ascendant he would taunt and insult, calling our mothers rather unmentionable things, and insulting Tang's growing culinary passion (I guess he got the last laugh there eh?), before shouting out terrible invocations and all manner of likely drugged speech. Tang, not to be left out, was foul mouthed as a sailor and would hurl an equal barrage of poor sportsmanship at Diego in his native tongue.
Myself, I enjoyed the simpler things in life. To savour a foe's destroyed Defiler spam, to silently pent my fingers in satisfaction as the AI (The Orklandian menace) stormed the bases of my frenemies, and of course, saving the re-plays of our matches to reinforce a revisionist version of events, as no one else ever did that and I was left with the sole truth of what happened.
In many ways, I miss those simpler times, those happier times. Before Tang was caught up in the legal incident with Miss Peller, before Diego ever made his first DOW3 map.
But those are tales for different times and different reviews.

Dawn of War is one of my all time favorite RTS series'.

While without mods I prefer Dark Crusade; SoulStorm is perhaps your best deal, especially with the Ultimate Apocalypse mod.  Three more races on top of the other nine, triple the tech tree size for all current races, vast amount of options.  It's beautiful...

2024 Update: I'm disappointed to report that SEGA has removed LAN support, but happy to announce that the Unification Mod is out, being updated, and is both better optimized and (for me) more fun than UA.  "What's the difference?" UA expands every core faction into 10 tiers with sub-faction options.  Uni only adds a tier 4 (and sometimes 5) keeping the scale of the original, but vastly expanding faction options while trying to maintain a semblance of balance (please nerf krieg and crons)

Dawn of War has always been a great game, to the point where I actually start hating it for the sake of hating it because later games get compared to it. This wasn't my childhood (that's Dark Crusade, the game that I was introduced to gaming through), but this game is great.

But, it isn't the absolute best.

But the best part is, it is the game that the DOW mod, Ultimate Apocalypse, was made for.

It takes a LONG time to get set up, and you need about 10 Gbs in total to get the whole thing, but it is so worth it! It expands the game in a way I can't even begin to dare say is bad! The mere fact that they made some factions in the game less effective at cheesy tactics, like Tau Empire stealthsuit rushing, gives them great advantage. Plus the extra rules are nice. And, this is the only RTS 40k game (mod or not) that gives Tyranids without the playstyle of Dawn of War 2, meaning structures like oldschool RTS games like Age of Empires and that. It's so good. And they play well too, not op, but not weak! And it keeps to the Dawn of War style of each faction being just as good as each other, just different playstyles to suit you.

Plus, the low cost of the game combined with the mod being no cost, AND the game being a standalone dlc, meaning you don't even need the original Dawn of War before this, makes this a must buy and download for any RTS fan.

Edit: As an extra edit, the Unification mod, which while incompatible with Ultimate Apolcalypse, adds a ton of new content to balance out all the factions and expand upon the game instead of absolutely breaking the game with op strategies. And it's even easier to get running too.
Try Unification Mod for 20+ more races, including Tyranids, Death Guard, Emperor's Children, World Eaters, Thousand Sons, Witch and Daemon Hunters, and MORE.

The last and in my opinion the goofiest Dawn of war expansion. Nothing against bringing in other studious to assist in the workload especially since GW has not changed even in these past decades still issuing punishing deadlines and crunch times to everyone even now 16 years later, But you can tell the other studio was not full of veteran devs let alone people who really had a clue what they were working on. However even despite all of that you still have a fantastic game considering you still have all of the previous stuff contained in the other expansions if you bought them (note I do believe you can still play all of them even if you didn't buy the expansions just not in multiplayer for some reason) , and the two new ones Sisters of battle and Dark eldar are an interesting bunch. 
Sister of Battle pack a lot of flame weaponry as to be expected for a entire army who likes to burn things tanks got flamers infantry flamers, melta guns, and generally can get way more use out of them in comparison to other factions who also have flame weaponry. The sisters are a bit of a mix between Space marines and the Guard you have as a general rule better tanks and more variety in the armored department and while not as strong as Space marines on the infantry side they are far cheaper in comparison. The Dark eldar are a high speed and damage faction that is able to output a large amount of burst damage and have a build system that promotes rushing down an early game opponent with some powerful units to keep up the pressure into the midgame. As I dont play the Dark eldar much I cant offer more of an explanation then that but I think they are solid. And as for the most important part of soulstorm and the reason many buy it..(drum roll)..MODS!

Ultimate Apocalypse is my go to and the mod I play even after unification's release it takes the 9 factions and kits them all out with some fantastic weaponry new buildings and more and In general is a great time so out of the two mods out there I would pick up UA-Ultimate Apocalypse there are plenty of videos on YouTube that show what both mods have to offer if you need a bit more info to understand what your getting into with the mods https://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-mod and https://www.moddb.com/mods/unification-mod-dawn-of-war-soulstorm both mods have a lot of love and time put into them and I would give each of them a shot

Probably one of the best Warhammer 40K games around. Even though this game is old enough to vote, it still holds it's classic RTS appeal. It shows it's age a bit compared to modern RTS games with a limitation on how much you can zoom out, and the graphics could definitely use a bit of an overhaul, but it's a SOLID RTS game. This is about as close to the tabletop experience you can get without the tedium.

I really wish there was a simple remaster of this game with a few quality of life enhancements to modernize it. In the meantime there are some great mods like Ultimate Apocalypse and Unification mods that add some solid additional content to the game.

In the past this game has been extremely buggy and difficult to work with however is maintaining the game is putting in tons of effort and I have yet to come across any significant bugs. I run this on Linux and it performs spectacularly. Also my favorite race to play is Sisters of Battle so I prefer this expansion over every other version of the game.

With all the mods out there, surely the best W40K rts imo.

To be honest, the Warhammer IP still lacks depth. The plot is always about killing and destruction, without construction, protection and love. This is mostly related to the poor values ‚Äã‚Äãof the West, which is always the law of the jungle, social Darwinism, and a society without any warmth.
I digress, let‚Äôs get back to the topic. As the fourth game in the Warhammer series, this game is pretty poorly done. The plot is completely empty and boring. So many races have been forced into the game, but the units do not have many characteristics, and are full of repetition and imbalance. There are also many vicious bugs in the game. For example, when a campaign is won, the game will crash incorrectly. If you don't save the game in advance, you will just cry. Another example, when you play a game at high resolution, your mouse cannot move to the right and down, which makes the game experience very bad.
In addition to the disadvantages mentioned above, the original flaw of the game have also been maintained. That flaw is the game's stupid and terrible AI pathfinding function. So I say it again, compared to the earlier releases of StarCraft 1 and Age of Empires 2, this game is really a complete garbage. I very much regret buying this game. If God gives me a chance to refund it, I will return it without hesitation.

Dawn of War 1 is quite simply better than any of its sequels due to the gameplay being a wonderful mix of base building and advancing your forces through tiers. Its fun, and very challenging. 

Now, if you want to get this game up to more modern standards? Unification mod is great, Its a bit of an annoying download, but its a must have.

Such a great RTS. No other Warhammer 40k game comes close. I enjoyed it much more than starcraft.

Instead of managing individual units this game innovated controlling entire squads that also allow some customization and attachment of leader units and support units. Resource gathering is simplified in that you just control points on the map and built energy generators. The art and atmosphere perfectly captures the warhammer 40k vibe.

Each faction has its own personality and unique strategies. The single player mode allows you to move around a map, manage defenses, fight battles with your commander and get persistent upgrades.

There are also some incredible mods that add so much more content to the game, but the downside is you will not use the steam workshop so you should be comfortable tracking down websites and installing the mods yourself.

The game is starting to feel a little dated with the UI and resolution, but it can still be fun.

One of my favorite games of all times. The game has several unique factions like dark elves, elves, orks, humans. The game is from 2003 and the title 'Soulstorm' is a DLC released in 2008. This game is the most played game in the DoW-series even though its almost 20 years old. And even though there were hundreds of players playing this game every day and you could easily join games, and you can still easily play it in the lobbies today. However, playing this game have been an exciting journey and it finally took me the 1000 hours of gameplay to beat the hardest difficulty in the game: 'insane' difficulty. So all in all, it's been a good time and I know consider this game finished and will get to pass to the graveyard of videogames with love.

A good game, better in some respects than Dark Crusade, but definitely worse in others. Mods can makes these games a lot better, both of them benefit from a camera mod that allows you to zoom out further, Soulstorm also benefits from a persistent bases mod, since the daft developers did not include that feature... in a base building game, although fairly simple/limited amounts of buildings and upgrades are available. There are a million other mods, many of which make both titles anything but vanilla.

But... The game is fatally flawed and was so even before Steam, the cutscenes that you get from defeating the faction home bases, crash the game. You can generally get around this by spamming the escape key just before the cutscene starts and keep doing so until you get to the battle summary screen. Some of the maps also appear to be unfinishable due to a fatal scar issue that occurs right when you defeat the map.The developer is clearly a piece of shit and so is steam.

I played this game for years before changing to steam and played every race in the game in both single and multiplayer not to mention the easly over 1000 hours put into this game over the years  most before the game was added to steam.

I can and am recomending this to anyone after an awsome warhammer 40k game or just someone who likes the idear of big armies fighting it out over loads of different maps.

this Game still has a good online player base nowhere near what it once was but still good considering the age of the game right my review is below sorry for the length but this game is worth it.

Multiplayer - A great part of the game, maps range in size from 2 players up to 8 players all different sizes and layouts some are over open where as others have choke pionts all over and some such as the Map 'Into the Breach' a 4 player map with a single choke piont really makes for awsome battles. the game is fairelly ballanced but of coursesome racesare better in certain ways and some like necrons are slowto get going but all are strong in thier own way, I have played all the races and can say their are all fun to use and in no way unplayerble. i would recomend before jumping into multiplayer going into the skirmish mode and having a few games on each race get a feel for them and how to build bases fast how to gain control as players who have played alot will have bases up very fast and be at your base before you know it and to finish this bit off you can also custom up your armies paint scheme and badges adds a nice touch to the game.

Campaign - Where to begin, to start with i shall say there is alot of hours worth of gameplay in it there is 3 moons and 4 planets to take space mariens, Tau and Orks start on one then Chaos and Dark eldar on one then Elder and Necrons followed by Imperial Gaurd and Sisters of Battle. The moons are just 1 province so 1 battle and each plannet has a stronghold for each faction and a decent number of provinces to fight for and each of them giving you planetry req which is basicly money for you to add certain units to your comanders Hounor Gaurd (once gained from taking certain provinces) and to reinforce provinces owned by you. it is a really fun game to play through I have played through on every race and some more than once on other difficulties.

Skirmish - I really enjoy this mode difficulties range from easy to insane from the computer, loads of maps and i mean loads, not much to say other than awsome mode lets to mess around try out new races and different play styles and new maps.

Mods - now this is one alot of people will be wanting, And for all of you i can say yes there are lots of mods for the game along with maps and more races and such which can be added, and if you fancy the idear of making maps or your own badges and banners for your armies you can there are modding tools out there which allow you to do that and it is very easy to do to get all this into the game is very simple and most mods will explain how below the badges and banners are abit harder if your new to it, I have a few mods currently installed and a couple of my favourites are the No limit mod which does as it says there is no limit to your army size when you play with this mod it is go big or go home, and the ultimate apocolipse mod which is an amazing mod with so much in units and buildings and a new way of playing as a new eliment to the game.

That is my Review for Dawn of war Soulstorm May the Emperor's Light guide you

Oldie but Goody. Build entire squads of most of our favorite factions from 40k. Take out your enemy (Or force them into a battle of attrition)

More of the last one, however instead of it being one planet (or one side of the planet) you have 4 planets and 3 moons to conquer, making things in the campaign much longer. You can no longer keep buildings in areas you conquered like the last game, unless  you have the forward basses ability. you can steal abilities off other races when you defeat them which gives you great boons and in this one two new groups appear. By far the most overrated RTS franchise I have ever encountered. I can't believe I got suckered by the nostalgia praise that was being heaped onto this game. 
To boil it down, this game only gets one thing right: the "look" of warhammer 40k. The units and vehicles are well designed and iconic. But, that's all it gets right. 
Path-finding in this game is horrific. God forbid, you select more than 2 units at a time to move; I have watched for over a minute while my units bump into each other like awkward prom dates while trying to move from point A to point B. 
Sync-kills (the stylish animation of one unit killing another) is rarely replicated in other RTS games. Do you want to know why? Because, it looks cool, but man, is it annoying to deal with. Basically, if an enemy demon decides your space marine's head would make for a good basketball, then you're going to watch it all take place in detail. That's not the problem. The problem is this: the enemy unit is invincible while the animation takes place, and your other units don't realize this. I've had half my firing line shooting at an enemy going through a 30 second animation while the other enemies take potshots at my guys who are exploding in bloody fountains. 
The campaign is tedious. You have to take strongholds ("boss fight" levels) which take easily 1-2 hours to complete. You have to complete a shopping list of objectives while the AI spawns infinite waves of units against your base meaning you have to inch your way through the level as you have to constantly maintain a base army as well as have your other army stumbling from one objective to another. 
It's not hard. It's just...boring. Like, I don't know how they did it but they somehow made battles involving space wizards, monsters, aliens, and desperate conscripts boring. That is impressive. 

I tried to like this game, purely because it does its presentation so well, but it does so many things wrong that I'm just not having any fun with it. If you're a die-hard 40k fan, you'll probably like this game; if you're looking for a decent RTS, then I'd recommend you look elsewhere.

This game is both the best WH40K game ever made and one of the best RTS games ever made. Contains tons of factions (9 in total, pretty much all the WH40K races except Tyranids, Tyranids are only in Dawn of War 2), tons of variety in different units, buildings and powers for each faction, and it has unique and interesting gameplay. This is the game everyone considers as "the" digital Warhammer 40K game. I have no idea why Relic isn't just making a remake or HD definitive edition of this with updated audio and visuals, because even if they added literally nothing to the game, it would still sell like hotcakes.

This game, even now, as of 2023 on Steam, is the 2nd most played Warhammer 40K game right after the one-year-old WH40K Darktide, and is the 5th most played Warhammer game overall. ...This is a 15 year old expansion to a 19 year old game. Let that sink in.

This is one of those classic RTS games that you might never get enough of - everything about this game is nearly perfect, from the amazing UI to the significant strengths and weaknesses of each race! The only thing that suffers is the campaign, being overly simple, lacking in interesting interactions between factions, and having no real interesting missions during the stronghold attacks. That being said, I still return to the campaign for the simple fun of conquering the system (Orcs FTW! WAAAUUGGHHHH!!!)

If you like RTS games, chances are you already have this one in your library. If you don't, what the fuck are you waiting for?

Sisters were probably the fuckin best thing to put in this game and even bringing in some new vehicles to the mix. I love air raiders in each army, brings a lot more to the table that was REALLY missing. Miss the Word Bearers from the previous games, but Alpha Legion is fine. 

Game's a lot bigger now and has the player play more objectives than Dark Crusade. Brings more variety to the game and more stakes. Drukhari (or Dark Eldar since this is based on Sixth Edition) have also been quietly added in. They're more melee based than their "good" counterparts, but that doesn't hold them back. They're squishy with a lot more abilities to save themselves from dying. Spells that make enemies hit softer, poisons that melt armor and flesh, chains dragging your innocent T'au commaders to their knees, so many good things to make this army feel unique. 

Great expansion, REQUIRED for full experience.

The single-player campaign in Dawn of War Soulstorm is inferior to Dark Crusade, despite the addition of two new factions, the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar. Why did they add Dark Eldar despite they cannot fight armies head-on, and prefer to raid planets with the least resistance and retreat to Commorragh once they get their slaves? They should have added Tyranids instead. Anyways in Dark Crusade when you build your structures on your territory, it becomes permanent so when the enemy attacks your territory all you have to do is build units and attack their base and it can be finished in a few minutes while in Soulstorm you to have to build it again which is tedious. The enemy stronghold in Dark Crusade is memorable because each stronghold has different objectives to defeat them while in Soulstorm all you do is attack this place and then attack that place. Oh, and they add flying units, which I barely use. But the good thing about Soulstorm is the mods for it, it adds a lot of new factions and enhances the game. Overall Soulstorm's single-player campaign is a downgrade compared to the previous Dawn of War games but Soulstorm is still enjoyable, especially since how many memes were made because of it.

The final standalone expansion of Dawn of War is often overshadowed by Dark Crusade due to it's lackluster total war style campaign, which is admittedly still pretty fun despite it being very flawed. Soulstorm also adds 2 new factions which are the extremely edgy Dark Eldar, and the Sisters of Battle, both are pretty fun to play and feel a lot more balanced in comparison to the Tau and the Necrons that were previously introduced in the last expansion. 

What Soulstorm does the best isn't actually part of the game as it is, rather it's the very strong and dedicated modding scene that the community for this game has built, there are many mods for soulstorm but 2 in particular stand out:
Ultimate Apocalypse: this mod maxes out the amount of units you can have on the battlefield at once, creating a very chaotic (and very laggy) experience that is very epic, it also adds new units to the factions as well.
Unification Mod: my personal favorite of the 2, it unifies most of the faction mods that are within Soulstorms modding scene into one package while also adding in some more making the total come to over 20 new factions to play as, and they are all very well made and have different game mechanics for each one making them all feel unique and there is more to come, not only that but all models have been updated and factions have been given new units AND these new units also have custom voice lines done by VAs that worked with the mod creators. The campaign has also been updated to make it more better than it was in the base game.

Unfortunately this game does have one massive downside that bothers me and that is the load times, they last pretty long and have a chance of just not loading at all and crashing your game, even with all the modding support there is nothing to fix this, but other than that, If you just need an excuse to play more dawn of war and really love the sisters of battle or the dark eldar then I would still recommend playing this, but trust me if you choose to play this without mods then you are definitely missing out on what I would personally consider the definitive Dawn of War experience.

Warhammer 40K Dawn of War Soulstorm is not only an amazing real time war strategy game, it also has a really well done story. You have to work for it, but it is amazingly well done. The graphics and sound are pretty good for it's time too. This is the 4th game in the series, so if you want the full story line, you'll have to start with 1; if you aren't worried about the overall story, then this game plays very well on it's own. It is good to note, however, that you will only have access to a couple of the races for online play if you only own this game. The other races are unlocked by owning and at least starting up the other games in the series. Overall, I would give this game an 8.5/10.

To this day, I haven't played an RTS that even comes close to replicating the sheer chaotic joy of Dawn of War. Some things haven't aged well of course, and there are much smoother, more accessible, more satisfying RTSs on the market, but there's nothing like the pure charisma and anarchy this game offers. It's also one of the first games I ever played, and one of the games my late father used to teach me, so I recognise that I have rose-tinted glasses, but I don't care. Love you dude.

This is one of my favorite games to play. Unfortunately, like so many other older games from Steam, it crashes constantly. Eventually, it gets to a point at which you can no longer play because it crashes every time between a victory and the return to the map screen. I've been playing Dawn of War off and on for years since its release in 2002, and I never had these issues when I was running it from a CD on much older computers, so I know this is a Steam issue. Steam offers no support because it is not one of their games, which is very poor customer service in my opinion. If you sell the game, you should provide support for it. While I would highly recommend this game, I would NOT recommend purchasing it from Steam. You might be able to still find the CD version around somewhere, or maybe purchase it elsewhere online like gog.com.

I have fond memories of both Dark Crusade and Soulstorm from my childhood, although Soulstorm does not hold up and has many flaws and shortcomings that I feel the community is well aware of. However, with Unification, this game turns into the game it should have been, and then some. Mods have kept this game alive for close to two decades. Even in 2023, with a huge selection of modern AAA games with exceptional graphics and modern gameplay mechanics, I still find myself coming back to Soulstorm Unification mod. There are also other mods such as Ultimate Apocalypse that have a more chaotic and varied lineup of units and game mechanics added, although I found UA a bit too complicated and unbalanced for my taste. Unification turns this game into something truly special. It's easy enough to install, and as of 2023 has a dedicated and talented team of people working to add new features and even more polish to it. Vanilla Soulstorm is neither here nor there, but Unification is a must play and will keep you entertained for hundreds if not thousands of hours. 10/10.

My childhood was in this game. I grew up with it. Despite this, I tended to favor DC bc of my bias really against anything that wasn't DC. I was told that this game was inferior to DC in many aspects. Years go by and I played this. I didn't play UA at the time, but I would soon find myself getting into that. Then Uni came out. I still didn't like vanilla bc I was stuck on Firestorm, thanks to how it handled power creep. I also didn't really like the fliers or the unit limits in SS, which is why I loved the no limit mod for both DC and SS. Uni had a vanilla balance to it, which I didn't like as much. Then I started to play vanilla to beat the skirmish maps. all of them, bc DOW SS campaigns felt more like playing those and better. That made like it better and I was playing all the races too so that gave me some variety. Playing the DOW AI mod also, made it better as well.

I came to like it more than I did previously and that mirrored my own development. When RTW get's buggy and bland, when M2TW bugs out, crashes, becomes boring, and the other RTS's I own become to much for me, DOW SS comes in. It's not the perfect RTS by any means, but it's one of the best IMO and the opinions of many others, bc of the mods that community brings out and the great base work of Relic's.

I've played all of the Dawn of War games (besides Winter Assault), and I have played for thousands of hours over many years. I can honestly say that this was my favorite. It had everything that I love about RTS games, strategizing, base-building and giant battles. With many mods throughout the years, the game has yet to get old, for me. I got a variety of map packs and the no limits mod for giant battles on new maps. I would recommend this to fans of sci-fi, RTS, base-building and war games. With this game being the place of the first Dawn of War Expansions, it includes all the races. So if you want to get a friend one of the DoW games, get them this one.
A good game if you want stimulating, not-too-intense gameplay.

It's good for modding. Unification and Ultimate Apocalypse are the most popular ones, both of which greatly enhance the base game. Unification builds wide while U.A builds tall in its design philosophies; Unification features many new races, some new gamemodes and goodies such as new rules and visual touch-ups across the board while Ultimate Apocalypse features new tech tiers and units allowing more replayability for existing content. 

The base game is admittedly inferior to the very good campaign on Kronus with a functionally smaller game map (despite being across a sector rather than planet for some reason), lack of bonuses missions (no more fight over the spaceport to be able to attack anywhere on the map or bloodsport to be able to take 2x turns) which limits your tactical consideration in the campaign or, worst of all, no banter between commanders during stronghold sieges. The two new races aren't lacking in their personality thankfully, but I simply don't find the new caster resource race (Dark Eldar) or the other new caster resource race (Sisters of Battle) fun as their race gimmicks are lackluster compared to others that share their specializations.

It has the funny Spess Mahreeens and bawkses speeches though. And Archon Tahril saying MYAAAH anytime he fails to capture something, which is very funny anytime it happens.

People describe this as an expansion in reviews but this is a STANDALONE game, just so people like me know who were a bit confused at first. What to say, improves all of DoW's mechanics and has all the races. Some are weaker than others(cough cough Tau), but other than that the map is 4 planets with multiple maps which you attack and defend from ai, basically take more land and as you take it you power up your leader and army through bonuses. The specific races added in this when compared to Dark Crusade are Sisters of Battle and Drukhari(Dark Eldar). Both of them are very fun and Drukhari have the builders be like Protoss from Starcraft 1 where you just let them place the building on the ground and it'll auto build while you can control them for other things, both Sisters and Drukhari have a 3rd bar that either fills up automatically or you can boost the amount it recharges with units and this 3rd resource is used for powerful AoE attacks or detection/healing magic. Just an amazing game and every RTS/Warhammer fan should play it

The strength of Soulstorm lies in its profound gameplay mechanics, offering a satisfying blend of strategic depth and engaging action. The game strikes a balance between intense gameplay and thoughtful planning, providing a rewarding and immersive experience for strategy enthusiasts.

The Unification Mod is an invaluable addition that further enhances the game's appeal. This mod seamlessly integrates all playable factions from previous expansions, including iconic forces like the Tau Empire, Necrons, and Tyranids.

Beyond faction diversity, the Unification Mod refines various aspects of the game, addressing balance concerns and improving overall gameplay. Additionally, the modding community's dedication is evident in their efforts to enhance visuals, refine AI behavior, and introduce new maps. These enhancements contribute to a more polished and immersive experience, ensuring that people can fully immerse themselves in the rich and captivating universe of Warhammer 40,000.

In conclusion, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War - Soulstorm, coupled with the Unification Mod, stands as a testament to the enduring quality of the RTS genre. Its profound gameplay mechanics, refined balance through the mod, immersive atmosphere, and the richness of the Warhammer 40,000 universe make it a standout title that continues to captivate people and deliver an exceptional RTS experience.

Dawn of War Soulstorm is the pinnacle of the Dawn of War collection. Its adds the sisters of battle and dark eldar factions to the roster, but on top of that, adds areal vehicles to every faction. On top of winter assault and dark crusade, soulstorm makes Dawn of War skirmishes immaculate. 

The campaign, like dark crusade, is a dynamic sandbox style campaign that has challenging scripted missions and skirmishes alike and is interesting and fun. I enjoyed being able to choose from ALL factions since I own dark crusade and winter assault. Of course, I chose imperial guard on my playthrough. 

I would 100% recommend this game to RTS fans and fans of Dawn of War.

Dawn of War - Soulstorm. An unwanted and largely unloved expansion for an amazing game that has now become the definitive version of Dawn of War. Ironic.

Soulstorm is an interesting title, in that unlike the previous two expansions (Winter Assault and Dark Crusade) it was not actually developed by Relic, but by a studio called Iron Lore Entertainment. The two factions it adds, Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle, are fun additions to the roster of factions from the base game and previous expansions, but sadly weren't balanced the best.

Campaign wise, it is an attempt at mimicking Dark Crusade's campaign. Keyword there being attempt. Instead of a single planet, the map has been "expanded" to four planets and three moons. Now, I say "expanded" because, in total, the map has gain a whopping six more territories since Dark Crusade, at the cost of making the map a chore to try and parse out. But don't worry, because the story isn't much better. It's absolutely riddled with plot holes, and is filled to the brim with stupid characters with stupid voices all making stupid decisions. Though, I suppose it's because they have such silly voices that even to this day you can make references to some of the sillier lines and have fans of 40k chuckle at the memory.

By now, I bet you're wondering why I recommend it, let alone describe it as the "definitive version of Dawn of War", right? Well it's simple. Modding. Soulstorm has, hands down, the most and some of the best mods out of all the expansions. There are a plethora of amazing mods, from Ultimate Apocalypse that expands the scope of the mod by adding three new factions along with massive amounts of units for all the preexisting factions, adding everything from the smallest grot to multi-skyscraper tall titans that can shoot across the entire map and destroy the enemy base in a single shot.

Another excellent mod you could try is the Unification Mod, which works with dozens of Mod creators to combine all of their individual faction mods into a single, ultimate mod. So it does not just add two or three factions, oh no, they have TWENTY NEW FACTIONS, and have updated the vanilla factions, and are planning on adding even more factions soon.

So, do I recommend Soulstorm for it's own merits? No. If you want well written characters and fun stories in a 40k strategy game, play the base game or either of it's first two DLCs. Or Play the Dawn of War II, or one of that games two expansions, Chaos Rising and Retribution.

But if you want to have a fun time with a great community playing some of the best modding has to offer, then welcome to Soulstorm.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Dawn of War: Soulstorm, the third expansion of the acclaimed Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War series by Relic Entertainment, takes players to the war-torn universe of the 41st millennium. As a seasoned fan of the series, I was eager to dive into Soulstorm and engage in epic battles, conquer new territories, and experience the intense strategic gameplay that has made the franchise a staple in the real-time strategy genre. Let's delve into the immersive world of Dawn of War: Soulstorm and explore why it remains a thrilling and satisfying addition to the Warhammer 40,000 universe.

[h1]Expansive Factions and Diverse Armies[/h1]
Soulstorm introduces two new factions, the Dark Eldar and the Sisters of Battle, expanding the roster of playable armies to a total of nine. Each faction brings a unique playstyle, complete with distinct units, abilities, and strategies. The vast array of customization options and army compositions ensure that no two battles feel the same, providing endless opportunities for experimentation and strategic depth.

[h1]Epic Campaigns and Engaging Storytelling[/h1]
Soulstorm offers an engaging single-player campaign that delves into the ongoing conflict in the Kaurava system. The narrative is captivating, filled with political intrigue, interstellar warfare, and the struggle for dominance. Each faction's campaign provides a different perspective on the conflict, allowing players to experience the story from multiple angles. The inclusion of memorable heroes and the choices that impact the outcome of the campaign add an extra layer of immersion and replay value.

[h1]Strategic Depth and Dynamic Battles[/h1]
The core gameplay of Dawn of War: Soulstorm remains true to the franchise's roots, providing a deep and satisfying real-time strategy experience. The game emphasizes resource management, base-building, and tactical combat. The addition of new air units, ground vehicles, and powerful superweapons introduces fresh dynamics to battles. The strategic control points on the maps create a dynamic and ever-changing battlefield, forcing players to adapt their strategies and constantly stay on their toes.

[h1]Stunning Graphics and Atmospheric Sound Design[/h1]
Soulstorm boasts improved visuals that bring the grim and gritty Warhammer 40,000 universe to life. The detailed unit models, destructive environments, and atmospheric effects enhance the immersion and create a visually impressive experience. The sound design, including the thunderous clash of battles, the booming weapon effects, and the iconic voice acting, adds an extra layer of authenticity to the game, further immersing players in the epic warfare of the 41st millennium.

[h1]Skirmish and Multiplayer Modes[/h1]
Dawn of War: Soulstorm offers a robust skirmish mode where players can engage in intense battles against AI opponents. The game's multiplayer mode provides an opportunity to test your strategic skills against other players from around the world. The competitive multiplayer scene, complete with ranked matches and a dedicated community, ensures that the gameplay experience remains challenging and engaging long after completing the single-player campaigns.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Dawn of War: Soulstorm successfully expands upon the rich universe of Warhammer 40,000, delivering a strategic and immersive gameplay experience. With its diverse factions, engaging campaigns, and dynamic battles, the game captures the essence of the franchise and offers countless hours of strategic enjoyment. Whether you're a die-hard fan of the series or a newcomer to the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Dawn of War: Soulstorm is a must-play for those seeking intense battles, deep strategic gameplay, and a journey into a dystopian future filled with epic warfare. Prepare to forge your path and conquer the stars in this thrilling addition to the Dawn of War series.

Don't let the apparent time on my Steam profile mislead you, I've spent far more hours glued to Dawn of War across its various iterations than it would appear. As a fan of strategy games both turn based and real time, I hadn't  delved into this gem until I got sucked into the WH40K lore by an ARPG gem by Neocore called Inquisitor - Martyr. Ever since I've been consuming games in the Warhammer universe, more on GOG than this site, and I adore the setting as a perfect backdrop for RPG and strategy gaming.

Dawn of War is what most RTS aspire to be, shaving off the distractions and adding features that dissuade the more annoying forms of play that would otherwise make some players a complete irritation to engage in multiplayer matches. By tying resources to "strategy points" on the map it makes the dreaded Turtle Defence suicidal and forces players to remain on the offensive. This makes for fast paced games where the only viable defence is a good offence, and the commander who most effectively deploys limited assets across the widest territory the surefire victor.

With squad based deployment, a wide range of potential assets, and truly varied factions that utilize their own economic systems, Dawn of War provides an army for every core style of tactics and provides a range of opponents that each require you to think carefully about how best to use the strengths of your own faction against the weaknesses inherent to your opposition.

In a rather unusual turn for the genre, the factions are fairly well balanced even without significant modding, and there isn't truly an obvious choice for easy domination. The more generalized a faction is the less suited to any given battlefield role they are. The often overpowered Space Marines of the Imperium find themselves nerfed by their own diversity in DoW, and helps to pry them from the pedestal they hold by virtue of the lore which has glorified their presence in this fictional universe.

Try outshooting the Tau with your army of Blood Angels and you'll soon realize that being big and tough isn't always the best asset on the field of war.

If you want fast paced tactics and a sci-fi war that will have you gripping your mouse with white knuckles this title can't be beat.

Dawn of War is a classic RTS featuring a unit control system that was relatively unique at the time of its release (squads).  Instead of controlling individual units, you primarily will control squads of units, unlike your basic concept RTS game.  The only exceptions to this are units that do not come in squads, such as vehicles and certain commanders.  
I highly recommend at least trying out the original Dawn of War game (now called "Dawn of War: Game of the Year Edition," if not every additional expansion.  
Soul Storm itself was an excellent finale to the series and should allow you to play every race available (9 total).

Do you see that?' he asked quietly. At first, only silence followed. Hesitantly, the Guard soldiers began to cast glances to each other, uncomfortable with the Chaplain's presence and confused by his behaviour. All eyes were on him now. Grimaldus aimed his mace out at the advancing hordes. Thousands. Tens of thousands. And only the very beginning. 'Do you see that?' he roared at the humans. The closest ranks flinched back from the mechanical bark that issued almost deafeningly loud from his skull helm. 'Answer me!' He received several trembling nods. 'Yes, sir‚Ä¶' uttered a handful of them, the speakers faceless within the masses behind their rebreather masks. Grimaldus turned back to the wasteland, already dark with the teeming, chaotic ranks of the enemy. At first, his helm emitted a low, vox-distorted chuckle. Within a few seconds, he was laughing, laughing up at the burning sky while aiming his crozius hammer at the enemy. 'Are you all as insulted as I am? This is what they send against us?' He turned back to the men, the laughter fading, but amused contempt filling his voice even through the inhumanising vocalisers of his helm. 'This is what they send? This rabble? We hold one of the mightiest cities on the face of the planet. The fury of its guns sends all skyborne enemies to the ground in flames. We stand united in our thousands - our weapons without number, our purity without question, and our hearts beating courage through our blood. And this is how they attack us? 'Brothers and sisters‚Ä¶ A legion of beggars and alien dregs wheezes its way across the plains. Forgive me when the moment comes that they whine and weep against our walls. Forgive me that I must order you to waste ammunition upon their worthless bodies.' Grimaldus paused, lowering his weapon at last, turning his back on the invaders as if bored by their very existence. His entire attention was focussed upon the soldiers below him. 'I have heard many souls speak my name in whispers since I came to Helsreach. I ask you now: Do you know me?' 'Yes,' several voices replied, several among the hundreds. 'Do you know me?' he bellowed at them over the firing of the wall-guns. 'Yes!' a chorus answered now. 'Iam Grimaldus of the Black Templars! A brother to the Steel Legions of this defiant world!' A muted cheer greeted his words. It wasn't enough, not even close. 'Never again in life will your actions carry such consequence. Never again will you serve as you serve now. No duty will matter as much, and no glory will taste as true. We are the defenders of Helsreach. On this day, we carve our legend in the flesh of every alien we slay. Will you stand with me?' Now the cheers came in truth. They thundered in the air around him. 'Will you stand with me?' Again, a roar. 'Sons and daughters of the Imperium! Our blood is the blood of heroes and martyrs! The xenos dare defile our city? They dare tread the sacred soil of our world? We will throw their bodies from these walls when the final day dawns!' A wave of noise crashed against his armour as they cheered. Grimaldus raised his war maul, aiming it to the embattled heavens. 'This is our city! This is our world! Say it! Say it! Cry it out so the bastards in orbit will hear our fury! Our city! Our world!' 'OUR CITY! OUR WORLD!' Laughing again, Grimaldus turned to face the oncoming horde. 'Run, alien dogs! Come to me! Come to us all! Come and die in blood and fire!' 'BLOOD AND FIRE!' The Reclusiarch cut the air with his crozius, as if ordering his men forward. 'For the Templars! For the Steel Legion! For Helsreach!' 'FOR HELSREACH!' 'Louder!' 'FOR HELSREACH!' 'They cannot hear you, brothers!' 'FOR HELSREACH!' 'Hurl yourselves at these walls, inhuman filth! Die on our blades! I am Grimaldus of the Black Templars, and I will cast your carcasses from these holy walls!' 'GRIMALDUS! GRIMALDUS! GRIMALDUS!' "

I have played a non-Steam version of this game and I can say for sure I have sinked in hundreds of hours into this game. Not a day goes by that I didn't wish this game still receive support or a remaster. It holds a very SPECIAL place in my heart.

What I believe makes this game stand out from others of its kind at the time is the limited number of units. Rather than allowing players to simply overpowered units and vehicles, the game restricts the player by allowing only small numbers of units and vehicles. Every unit is a valuable resource each with their own strengths and abilities. And it's up to you to make the most of it. 

Despite my fond memories of this game, I still find it flawed in terms of balancing but still a fun and enjoyable game nonetheless. The pathfinding system for instance is perhaps the single most game-breaking feature of this game. It is frustratingly terrible, with units getting stuck on narrow places, or vehicles blocking the route. 

I would still recommend it to players, especially those who are new to the Warhammer 40, 000 universe.
I also played a non-steam version of this so I got way more than 75 hours. Definitely recommend it. Slap the Ultimate Apocalypse mod onto it and enjoy massive battles.

If I could give a Mixed review, I would. This is a "Mixed" standalone expansion for a great game. I've been pondering quite long on whether to mark it as a positive or a negative review - the former I feel might be misleading, whereas the latter might be cruel. It truly is a mixed experience, with both good and bad.

Provided it's on sale or you get it in a package with all the others, and you're already a fan of the game or the setting, I think it's worth it. If this is somehow your first foray into Warhammer and Dawn of War, please just get the base game or Dark Crusade instead.

The pros of Soulstorm are easily visible. Two new factions, both with a very cool aesthetic. It introduces new units, new mechanics, new maps, and a new campaign. All of this is good - I mean, come on, it's the Dark Eldar and the Sisters of Battle. Bar a couple exceptions like the Tyranids, it also means the game has pretty much everyone from the setting, and you can pit them all against each other.

Getting it for the skirmish mode alone might be worth it to you, though that depends.

The cons, however, are hard for me to pinpoint exactly. They are hard for me to see, but I can definitely feel them. Something is *off* when comparing it to the base game or the previous expansions. The new factions feel clunky and strange, and though maybe this is because I do not have enough hours in them, I still find myself picking others instead. They *look* fun, but they do not *feel* fun.

Cool to try once, and then go back to the other ones. This may be personal opinion, but I'm sure many feel the same way. There's something tedious or stiff about the ability meters, something lacking or perhaps somehow off-balanced about the unit roster. Something about the power bar that just feels... I don't know. Gimmicky? Somehow, even the Necrons with their out-there mechanics feel better to play, at least in my opinion.

Plus, there's a notable lack in polish and a drop in quality in certain aspects. Every so often, a crusty .jpeg will greet you instead of some better-looking icon, or a unit of one of the new factions will fail to play any animation if it's taken out in some unexpected way. Nothing truly game-breaking or upsetting, but again, continuing the *off* theme of the expansion.

The variety is welcome, but it's not really good variety. It's just... variety. Not terrible, but not excellent.

Then there's the campaign, which is pretty much just Dark Crusade except worse. More tedious. It asks you to hunt down every single crumb of enemy on the map, every single battle. Combined with the slow loading times even on modern PCs, I found myself often questioning the ratio of waiting (whether in the loading screen, or for my units to sweep the map for that one last plasma generator or whatever the enemy was hiding) to playing. *Tedious* is the word. Unfun might be another.

It feels like such a small change, but it transformed the fun experience of Dark Crusade into one that is hardly enjoyable, or even frustrating. Whereas Dark Crusade's campaign had me eagerly waiting to come back home and boot up my computer to play more, Soulstorm's campaign had me eagerly waiting the sweet release of the quit button.

Is it a bad game? No, not really. But I think it does deserve its place as the black sheep of the Dawn of War 1 variants. Of the base game and the other two expansions, it is the bottom ranking for me - and many others. On its own, it's... *fine.* Playing a bit of Skirmish is still fun. It's still Dawn of War.

Again, if you're just starting out, get the base game. If you're here for the cool overworld campaign content, get Dark Crusade. But on a discount or in a pack, Soulstorm is still worth a shot. If you just want to Skirmish as the Dark Eldar or Sisters of Battle, it's good enough for that. Even if it's a bit scruffy, at the end of the day it's more Warhammer. Plus, I hear the Unification mod is extremely good, though I've yet to try it.

Dawn of War: Soulstorm is an excellent real-time strategy game that offers a unique and immersive gameplay experience. If you're a fan of the genre, then this game is definitely worth checking out.
The single-player campaign is the standout feature of Soulstorm. It takes players on a journey through the galaxy as they battle to gain control of the mysterious planet of Acheron. With nine different factions to choose from, each with their own unique play style and units, the campaign remains engaging and challenging throughout.
In addition to the single-player campaign, Soulstorm also offers a range of multiplayer modes that provide players with the opportunity to test their skills against other players from around the world. The game's online functionality is seamless and easy to use, and the community is still active to this day.
But what really makes Soulstorm stand out is its deep and intricate gameplay mechanics. The game requires a lot of strategic thinking and careful planning, which makes every match feel like a satisfying puzzle to solve.
The graphics and sound design in Soulstorm are also impressive. The game features beautiful environments and detailed unit designs, which make battles feel epic and immersive. The music and sound effects are also top-notch, which helps to create a truly immersive gaming experience.
Overall, Dawn of War: Soulstorm is an excellent game that offers a lot of depth and replayability. If you're a fan of real-time strategy games, then you won't be disappointed with this one

Soulstorm inherited the strengths of the base game Dawn of War, but it also introduced a ton of new, annoying bugs that have never been fixed. Some examples:
[list]
[*]Crashes: The game crashes after most stronghold missions and sometimes randomly, in the middle of a mission or skirmish game.
[*]Honor Guard Units: The computer gets honor guard units out of thin air, i.e. the Orc computer player owns 3 districts, but has 9 honor guard units. Even worse: They don‚Äôt die! When you defeat their commander and his honor guard, it gets moved to an adjacent district without any losses.
[*]Bugged AI: On the campaign map, the AI sometimes gets stuck. It never attacks an enemy, even when it has strength 1 districts next to it. The Orc computer player i mentioned before hasn't left its 3 districts for over 10 turns, even tough it could steamroll its neighbors with 9 honor guard units. 
[/list]
Another major problem are the nonsensical difficulty levels. There are 3 levels: Easy, normal and hard. Easy and normal are boring because it‚Äôs almost impossible to lose because of the huge hitpoint buffs your units get. Hard difficulty is a different story. Your units don‚Äôt get any buffs and the computer player gets 20% extra hitpoints. This slight advantage for the computer makes it extremely hard to deal with its immortal honor guard units, which will be in your base like 1min after game start. So you have the choice between boringly easy and frustratingly hard.

When you combine the many new bugs and the nonsensical difficulty with the terrible unit path finding from the base game that Soulstorm hasn‚Äôt improved at all, you get a gameplay experience that is just frustrating most of the time. The previous Dawn of War addons were great, but this one is a mess.

-> The game is really cheap for its good quality 
Conclusion: if you like RTS and Warhammer go for it.

[h1]"We go where we wilt. We slay who we wilt. Let the Emperor judge the righteousness of our deeds."[/h1]

[b]NOTE:[/b] This covers the campaigns only, not the skirmish or multiplayer modes.

Dawn of War: Soulstorm is the final expansion for the original game. Following up and expanding on Dark Crusade and the new mechanics introduced therein, Soulstorm makes some relatively minor but far-reaching changes to the gameplay, and many seem to not be for the better. Similar to its predecessor, Soulstorm plays like a game of Risk - only this time, there are four distinct planets in a system across which the conflict is spread. There are also two new factions to contend with: the Dark Eldar (which do not add much to the mix in my opinion), and the Sisters of Battle (which seem to be pretty OP, at least in campaign mode). Flying units have also been added to all races except for the Necrons - which also do not really add much to the mix; the maps do not seem to have been designed with this in mind. Mission wise, the addition of Take and Hold conditions, where you need to hold critical locations for a certain amount of time to win, is a welcome change to the normal "Annihilate" mission objective and does help to vary the pace.

With that being said, there are some regressions (you decide how much these matter):
[list]
    [*]I had issues with capturing points; often your army will stand around and do nothing - might have to do with army size. To be fair, I experienced this in Dark Crusade as well, just not as often.
    [*]I often lost track of my cursor on the screen, especially when it was busy - there may be a mod to address this, but nothing in the native settings.
    [*]Three warring Imperial factions does not sit well with me (Dark Crusade already left a bit of a sour taste). Surely that is not right?
    [*]The lack of characterisation of the leaders is disappointing, especially when contrasted with Dark Crusade (although Gorgutz is still funny, with the few lines he has). The interplay between warring faction leaders was a high point in the previous game.
    [*]Perhaps most importantly - your structures no longer remain when defending territory. This becomes INCREDIBLY annoying as you essentially have to start from scratch in defense missions. Why would your buildings not be in place if you already hold territory? Thankfully, this can be addressed to a degree with a mod (more below).
[/list]
These factors add up to take the edge off Soulstorm for me, but they can be mitigated to a degree with mods.

[b][u]Mods[/u][/b]

I avoided any major or total overhaul mods. My playthroughs consisted of the below:
[list]
    [*]Soulstorm Bugfix Mod (https://www.moddb.com/mods/soulstorm-bugfix-mod/downloads).
    [*]Better Camera Mod (https://www.moddb.com/games/dawn-of-war-soulstorm/addons/camera-mod-for-dow) - default is too zoomed in for my liking.
    [*]Persistent Campaign Bases Mod (https://www.moddb.com/games/dawn-of-war/downloads/soulstorm-persistent-campaign-bases-mod-v14) - this helps a great deal to reduce frustration when defending provinces.
[/list]
Ordinarily, you can only have one mod active at a time - but by using the Mod Manager (https://github.com/Fragjacker/DoW-Mod-Manager), you can bypass this by essentially making one mod a requirement for the other, so that both are loaded. Exercise caution though, as you can create problems if using this method with big mods. More help can be found at the PCGamingWiki page: https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Warhammer_40,000:_Dawn_of_War:_Soulstorm

Finally, I experienced crashes at the end of every campaign but this helped to get the game going again: https://www.reddit.com/r/dawnofwar/comments/krz92u/fix_to_the_failed_to_initialize_video_card_pop_up (essentially, overwrite the files in the folder from the archive, reinitialise, and go again).

As to the age-old question of Dark Crusade or Soulstorm: on balance, I would say Dark Crusade. It is a bit bland, feels like development was rushed and it lacks the charm and engagement of the previous games (in vanilla guise). That being said, Soulstorm is still Dawn of War, and you cannot go far wrong with it.

This game was good, then I found the Ultimate Apocalypse mod. It gives you the real imperial guard feeling of throwing millions of lives at an enemy to hold them back while artillery shells them from afar.  The base game is great as well but once you get into the modding aspect, there's no going back. UA adds Tyranids, approximately 12 more units per army, Titans completely adding a new sense of scale to the game, and even new vehicle variants, character abilites, and gamemodes.

tldr: If you like Supreme Commander or Warhammer 40k get this game and mod it. The Ultimate Apocalypse mod is my go to, but Titanium Wars and the Unification mod are both great options.

[h1] Hersey grows from idlest. [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ A classic RTS game.
+ Lots of factions to choose from. ([i]With all other D.O.W games included [/i])
+ Community is still going strong.

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Multiplayer server connection issues/connecting issues.
- The Dark Elder were introduced in this game.

[b] The Singleplayer Aspect [/b]
You can play one of [strike] had to google this [/strike] nine races In a risk turn style campaign where your one goal is galaxy dominations! You start in specific zone to your race slowly growing and fighting your way through every faction to be the last faction standing. Every time you fight a different faction you put in a loading screen and play a 1v1 with that faction on a map. Depending how many units you attack with is how easy or hard it will be to take out the enemy base. The singleplayer aspect is very fun to get some practice in for when you play multiplayer. 

[b] The Multiplayer Aspect [/b]
The majority of this game I have played I have played with friends. You can play against AI or with players depending on how you feel. It's an old game so expect connection problems every often. There's a great chance when you launch up the multiplayer tab of the game you will find online match's to join if you don't have friends just expect to get bodied for going against try hards. 

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
If your going buy this game then you better own all the other Dawn Of War 1 games because buying it alone otherwise just isn't worth it. With all the other down of war expansion games combined it's worth the price. 

[h1] Final Score 10/10 [/h1]

I re-bought the Dawn of War collection. I remembered how good Dawn of War series was and I have the physical discs hidden away some where. About 20 years later it was time to revisit this series. It was time to dive back into greatness. 

Sadly things did not go as well as I hoped they would. The first issue I ran into was I couldn't get the game to run at 1920 x 1080. That's unfortunate. But I still had a lot of fun with the story and the run through Dawn of War was a lot of fun. Entertaining story and the combat was great.

I then moved on to the DLC. Starting with the Winter Assault. At first I was having fun, I decided to play the bad guys and goodness, they have you jump through some strange balancing act hoops to complete missions. The story felt lacking. It wasn't as good as I remembered it. Maybe I played the good guys. The DLC was okay. 

Then I came to the spiral... I must have mentally blocked the next 2 DLCs. I could have sworn they were good but.... Both seem to have little to no story and you fight on what appears to be just multiplayer maps. It was the start of the lazy developer phase. What was considered balancing was limiting unit types and everything seemed to come across as tanky. I mean, heavy bolters against guardsman should melt them right? Think again. Not even with tech maxed. It all felt spongy. 

Dark Crusade and Soulstorm are just wash, rinse, repeat grind as you fight to secure the map for your faction. On normal the AI feels tanky, but not unbeatable. This made these 2 DLCs feel like a time sink and not as entertaining. 

I would highly recommend the first Dawn of War. I wouldn't bother with the DLC. They just try to ruin the experience you had playing the first one.

Out of any other game that is set within Warhammer 40,000, Dawn of War takes the cake. While the campaign for Soulstorm isn't the best, Dark Crusade has that honor. What Soulstorm has over Dark Crusade is the multiplayer. It has all of the factions which is massive positive, but you will need to own the previous expansions and base game.

In the Grim Darkness of the future there is only War. Soulstorm is an excellent expansion of the series, Dawn of War. I highly recommend the series, as it can lead to addicting hours of play, alone or with friends. It is friendly with many computers of all ages, and there are good mods that can extend how much you play this game. (Ultimate Apocalypse is my favorite mod, as it is more fluff friendly.) Recommended for those new to the universe and those who are veterans in the galaxy of war. Fight in His Glorious name, the God-Emperor of Mankind, or for the Ruinous Powers of Chaos, or even perhaps in the name of the Xenos who fight for their own ends. You decide, and you shall carve into history. 
    The story of the series is wonderful in itself, although not as grand or as well told as the first or Winter Assault. Dark Crusade and Soulstorm non the less allow for a fun twist of domination for the sector. They tie in slightly with the Dawn of War II series, but are not necessary for DoW II. 

(Note: Multiplayer comes with its own race from each game. GotY/Gold gives Space Marines, Orks, Eldar and Chaos. Winter Assault grants the Imperial Guard. Dark Crusade allows for Tau and Necrons. Soulstorm itself grants the zealous Sisters of Battle and the dreaded Dark Eldar. If you also get the Ultimate Apocalypse Mod, you receive more units in each faction, as well as adding the Ordo Maleus' Daemon Hunters and the Tyranids.)

[b]This is a terrible expansion. I highly recommend it.[/b]

Let me elaborate a little:

Soulstorm has a campaign that is a slightly increased scale rehash of Dark Crusade's. The balancing is awful, the writing is laughable and has spawned many memes, it's riddled with unfixed bugs, and there's just a general lack of quality going on here likely caused by the outsourcing of development to a third party rather than being made by Relic itself.

[b]HOWEVER.[/b] Soulstorm is the home of some extremely high quality modifications that add an insane level of detail to the game and in some cases also increase the scale to Epic 40k levels. They're amazing experiences that every 40k and RTS fan should experience, and if you have any experience with other Dawn of War games or pre-Soulstorm expansions, I highly recommend picking this up just so you can play those modifications. This is one of those few situations where I truly do believe a game is worth its asking price not because of what it offers itself, but what the community has done for it over the last 15 years.

Out of all of the expansions for DoW, Soulstorm is without a doubt the worst. Despite being the newest, it has the most issues running on current systems, with for example the campaign not being playable for me, because the game crashes when ending the first battle. From what I heard, there's other issues, from smaller to larger that I haven't encountered, but you may. 

Aside from that, it is definitely the most derivative, and is more like a unit and map pack to Dark Crusade, rather than being a true expansion in line with Winter Assault, and the mentioned DC. It adds two new factions - space marines, but women, and even edgier eldar. The campaign, on first glance, looks to have expanded in scope, but in actuality, although it claims to be taking place on multiple planets, still only really has one grand map, and the amount of provinces is still roughly the same as in DC. The last addition are "air" units, which are really just land units floating in the air, largely constricted by the same map accessibility limitations, but somehow with even worse pathfinding than regular land units.

All in all, Soulstorm is quite a soulless experience. Dawn of War released in 2004, WA in 2005 and DC in 2006... and then Cashgrabstorm in 2008 because I guess the publisher wanted to cash in on the still very popular game. Still though, the basic Dawn of War / Dark Crusade game loop applies, so if you get it as part of the whole DoW package, there's no reason not to try it out, just don't expect anything extra from it and go in with the understanding that the campaign may not work at all and you will be restricted to skirmish and multiplayer.

On it own though, it definitely cannot be recommended, even with its current price.

Also, Necrons are still a pain in the azz. Phuck the Necrons.
Campaign is stale as all hell and when you take a stronghold, the game crashes.

It's bad. For positive aspects, it offers little, it's a slightly expanded take on the Dark Crusade system, and it's Dark Crusade 2.0. Dark Crusade was a fantastic game, and so everything good about that is mostly present here.
HOWEVER.
1) it's so buggy. The AI on units seems to have been broken by the studio that made Soulstorm. Units get stuck on each other far more often, but also there's a bug where cycling through e.g. builder units selects them all, without pressing any modifier or extra button. You're wondering why your building in the back isn't finished - it's because the builder unit making it ran across the map to join his friend. Also Units are weirdly sticky with targeting. The whole interface just feels broken. Not to mention the crashes and general instability.
2) The story is lazy and poorly made. This is not Dark Crusade, it's scuffed.
3) The unit balancing is poor and they even managed to mess up things that made Dark Crusade great. Persistent buildings between battles are gone, no more benefit for exploring the entire map in the story campaign. The graphics somehow seem worse, with the charm stripped.
Just google how to mod Dark Crusade and save your money, the mods will be more stable than this.

Warhammer 40k Dawn of War 

This game, and many of the games in the series meant more to me growing up than I'll ever be able to adequately express. Dawn of War came out in 2004 and it was revolutionary, a game from that time with mechanics and graphics that blew a lot of things people were used to out of the water; rich in lore and immersive as all hell. I'm sure I don't have to go into detail about all the ways this games core mechanics were astounding, or how the Campaign was magnificent, I know for a fact there are many people who can explain all of this better than I ever could.

Many people review games based on their nostalgia and their own experiences, so I'll make the honest attempt at explaining just how much this series has meant to me throughout my life, and why I can't recommend it enough.

When I was quite young, I'd experienced quite a few traumatising incidences that made me  very ostracised growing up. I was given Dawn of War by my parents and this game helped me find an escape from a lot of the turmoil I'd felt daily, and it offered me a bit of respite where I could find none in sleep. 

I've had Post Traumatic Stress Disorder for almost as long as I can remember, and through this game I actually managed to meet some of my first friends in school as they were very like-minded with Warhammer, and I was even able to get through my days easier. I'd found an outlet for a lot of my grief and anger, and it allowed me to find some form of relaxation in a time where I was nearly always debilitatingly anxious, even playing it to the point of falling asleep, something I'd often struggled with as I had, and still have quite terrible nightmares. 

I'd proceeded to buy almost every Warhammer 40k or Warhammer Fantasy game that came out on sheer principle alone, and whilst the games changed drastically, I've always been a steadfast fan, to the point that my next tattoo is going to be Warhammer related.

This game series meant a lot to me, from allowing me to make some of my first connections to people, to being one of the driving forces in my appreciation for storytelling and voice acting. Because of this, Warhammer 40k will always be my favourite franchise. 

I do wish Games Workshop would've listened to their fans, and stuck with the direction their games had started with, and managed to maintain their upwards trajectory as a company. Dawn of War 3 was fundamentally disappointing, but the first game, and the games leading up to Dawn of War Retribution will always be great games, and the Dawn of War series will forever remain a pillar of the RTS genre.

As coming back to this review I will say this has definitely earned to absolutely be my top favorite Real Time Strategy genre game out there, with tons secret stuff [spoiler]MODDING and making MODS[/spoiler] to do in this game I discovered, I've been just completely hooked on playing this game since lock-downs happened in 2020, I've come a long ways with what I discovered to do in this game.  I have much more to learn and master at, [spoiler]I even just released an update to a mod I made for this game in the Steam Community page as well. 
 It's called "[b]J.S.T.'s Original PDF-IG From DoW-GotY DoW-S Mod[/b]" guide page[/spoiler] you can check it out if you're curious enough about it.  :)

As for the base vanilla Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War - Soulstorm game itself, I will honestly uphold it as something I come back to in RTS, it's a real fun way of getting into the Warhammer 40,000 lore, or at least glimpse of it that is.  This expansion also has the most variety of factions/races to be in Single Player mode, Offline Skirmish mode as well, on top with having all of the previous expansions you get to be all 9 factions in online Multiplayer Mode.  Relic Entertainment did a fantastic job at making these games, this expansion [strike][i]would probably have been so much more if they didn't leave Iron Lore to work on it by themselves, but Iron Lore you guys/gals did your best considering R.E. left you all to work on this game.[/i][/strike] especially has a lot new stuff compared to its previous expansions.


So as of this review update, I uphold this game and its expansions as my top RTS games out there.  :D

The first time I played it I was probably 18 in 2005, barely remembered it. Spent years disregarding it as "too old" and "too ugly" to be played. Picked it up again a month ago to scratch a 40k itch.

Dawn of War is one of the best RTS of all time. The animations are amazing, the graphics are dated but incredibly cool, tanks with mobile parts galore, absurd firefights with massive volume of fire and chunky, visceral sounds make playing Dawn of War and its expansions an absolute treat. 

Plus, the modding scene is deep and ambitious, grab Unification, Titanium Wars, Ultimate Apocalypse or Crucible and enjoy dropping nukes on your enemies, summon massive titans to trample them underfoot while blowing them to bits, it's just pure fun.

There are some amazing mods for this game, off the top of my head:
Ultimate Apocalypse (my favourite),
2gb patch mod
Titanium wars
and
Unification Mod, which combines:
Bugfix mod
Almost every race mod
Extended view cam
Stronghold Mod
and Survival, the art of defence.

Unmodded however, just get Dark Crusade, unless you intend to play multiplayer, in which case, races are locked until you buy the relevant DLCs, and this games campaign is the weakest of the DOW franchise (excluding DOW 3, which is a bad game through and through), the balance of this game in skirmish mode, excluding the air units, is better than Dark Crusade, Dawn Of Eldar.

If you can mod this game, get it, it's amazing modded, and the balance for skirmish mode is better than dark crusade, but its campaign is the worst of the bunch, and if you intend to play multiplayer, get all of the DOW1 games or use a race unlocker mod.

TL;DR: pick up on sale, good game, better with mods, 7/10

If you like a sort of slow, creeping style of strategy game, this is a good one.  Unlike DOW II, which is a bit more fast paced, this is more similar to "Warcraft 2" in the slow, base-building, resource acquisition style.  Lots of races to choose from, so expect a lot of time well spent as you explore all the options.  Personally, I like the Tao, and the Necrons.

Every now and again you find a game that sets the benchmark for every other game like it, and Soulstorm is one of those games.  Most 4x TBS games I play I end up saying "it's no Soulstorm."  Every other Warhammer game that I've played (and subsequently gave a thumbs down) I've said...it's no Soulstorm.

Soulstorm's Planetary Conquest mode just has this unique mix of TBS and RTS elements that seamlessly blend together.  Yea, it's dated, the graphics are old, the game is old, you can only beat it so many times before it becomes pointless, but still...It was fun in it's day and nothing has rose to the challenge of being quite like it.

It was the lone gem to be had out of the rubbish that was Warhammer.
