[h1]Warhammer¬Æ 40,000: Dawn of War¬Æ - Soulstorm[/h1]
Warhammer¬Æ 40,000: Dawn of War¬Æ - Soulstorm is the sequel to Dark Crusade. And to start with, I will not divide this review into chapters, because it's not worth it. It is basically a copy of the previous game, the only thing different about this is that apparently the evolution in Dawn of War is going backwards. Nothing has been fixed, it's actually even worse. In the very intro of the game, one of the important characters from the previous game just dies. The Battle Sisters and Dark Eldar appear on the battlefield, and they genuinely bored me with their mechanics. Somehow it felt like they were slightly detached from the other factions (I would prefer the Tyranids). And now the Tau are wearing bright red armor. I don't know why, it looks a bit silly (and the Necrons are now black and bright blue, it also looks very strange). Battle maps were pissing me off, for some reason I can never find an enemy base, and every battle takes a lot of time by forcing me to search for the enemy all over the map, and the tiny font and shit camera don't help me with this. Cutscenes are okay, but you can quickly guess that they did not want to fine-tune them and ultimately when watching them you feel confused and bored, they lack spirit. And what about the most important asset to this game, the campaign map, now the size of several planets connected by the Eldar gates? From the first point of view, it sounds great. But you quickly notice the absolute stupidity of the AI that mindlessly rushes into a fight, and a shitty balance of the game, which makes it either too easy or too damn hard to do anything. The fact that the game is unstable and often crashes to the desktop does not help, forcing us to play larger battles again and again without end. And don't get me wrong, most of the positive things from the previous game show up here as well, but it doesn't balance with what was broken and done poorly.

Chaos made manifest. A fun game you can forget time with; unfortunately, let down by some maps whilst also having some very well-designed maps dotted throughout. 

The base game is fine alone, but with the free mod "DoW Ultimate Apocolopyse", this game quickly puts itself on par and above current games. 

It feels great as an underdog to build a steady defence that evolves into a rolling attack over enemy territory, especially against the Orks and Blood Ravens. The campaign is engaging and straightforward, destroy the enemy and reinforce your domain so they can't push back. Still, the wargear customisation and in-game battles are stellar. 

There's a wide variety of units and different factions to play around with, from the Imperium heavy armour and large unit count to the Sisters of Battle specialised units with specialised weapons and tactics. I have a lot of fun playing as and playing against all of the factions.

The only negative with the game I can find is that some non-HQ maps are annoying to see twice. I know the Orks gave me grief when I had to fight in some defended territory, which you can Auto-Resolve, but I personally wouldn't put that up to chance.

I have played and re-played the Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War series at least 4 times.  The first release is pretty straightfoward, but each additional add-on increases the depth while keeping the spirit of the game alive.  It is easily playable in Normal mode for those who don't game full-time and the "fun" of building a maxxed-out army and demolishing the foe is a blast.  You can always play as a different race of beings and do it all over again.

Note:  BEFORE YOU FINISH A LEVEL/MATCH...SAVE.  The game (not system) has frozen after spending an hour playing a level and all is lost!  Save! Save! Save!  There are bugs going back YEARS that haven't been addressed and never will.  You've been warned!

The base game is lots of fun. Air craft aren't the best in vanilla, but the two new factions that come with it (Sisters and Dark Eldar) are loads of fun. 

The campaign is fun, with the unique missions at strongholds which are very fun and unique. Each faction has their own starting trait which you can unlock, each of them fit the faction very well. 

For gameplay, it's the same as before, just with air craft that work mostly fine. Mostly. When they get stuck it's super annoying and feels like a waste when you see your super expensive plane stuck on a cliff side. Sisters are an amazing anti infantry faction with flame throwers and are one of my favourite factions (other ones being Eldar and Guard). Dark Eldar have some very fun unique mechanics with the Slaves and Souls. 

Base game is a 8.5/10. Where it gets to 10/10 is with the sheer amount of mods.

Mods for this game are great. If you want base game with more factions, you can add unique faction mods (Deamons, Tyranids, Dark Angels, Blood Angles, etc.). If you want titans and massive battles, Ultimate Apocalypse and the many sub mods are there. If you want a middle ground with many different options and new game modes, Unification is there.

I recommend this game with the first game collection, especially  when it's on sale. I got it for around $6 CAD. Amazing game.

Very fun RTS set in the Warhammer 40K universe. Visually and audio-wise this game is flawless managing to capture the grim dark feel of the setting. This game's voice acting in particular is superb. The game is also just plain fun from a pure gameplay standpoint although some of the additions made in this specific entry are not flawless (flying vehicles specifically feel disappointing). That being said this also the DOW entry with probably the biggest mod support. From simple gameplay enhancement mods to total conversion mods bringing half a dozen more playable factions and fleshing out the already existing factions with modern tabletop units. An essential entry for all Warhammer 40K fans.

I'd like to start, I do recommend this game because think of it like a big asset pack. The expansion itself is terrible, but what modders can really really polish this turd into the game we all wished it would have been.

I like how my first review for this was "funny" but whatever. Yes, bitch and moan all you want over my review but Soulstorm is the worst expansion in the series. Dawn of War 3 is more desirable than the vanilla soulstorm expansion.

First off this comes out after the amazing campaign of Winter Assault, and the groundbreaking Dark Crusade. Crusade was Warhammer at its ABSOLUTE finest. The maps were incredible, the new factions were diverse and unique, and the sandbox storytelling actually had me intrigued. Then in the online mode, there was just a mountain of ways to take down your opponent which lead to every experience being a thrill ride of fun. I played orks because I could rush the free ork tech. Spam Orky boyz at the problems i wanted to go away, and then use all my ork vehicles to hit critical targets while my opponents were ground down in my never ending green tide.

Enter Soulstorm. The campaign is nonsensical and has 1/1000th of the effort put in. The story is a Warpstorm is coming to wipe out the system and everyone has a plan to prepare for the coming end times. Seems like a cool premise like Endless Legend. However its executed horribly like when Chaos laughs that people hide in tanks "METAWL BAWKSES" and its just such bad voice over work you just cant stop laughing.

The maps are so terrible in every possible way. Many of them are Asymmetrical which just leads to you trying to outspam the AI to wipe out their base which is immediately next to you your own base. Its less about exploring and map control, and more like watching creeps fight in league of legends. Additionally, look at maps in dawn of war, winter assault, and dark crusade. They have tiny little details everywhere that makes each map look like an intricate and exciting place to explore. Its truly fun fighting it out. 

There's a couple maps that seems like they started to try on, but the vast majority of new maps look like they pulled them from a community map pool. They are lazy blob messes, they look gross and the immersion is ruined when you see error cubes, pink blobs, and low res textures being stretched across the map, and this happens on a staggering amount of new maps.

Next up, the game was balanced for a tried and true formula. Infantry and Mechanized combat. Infantry can be specialized to take down all kinds of opponents, and really it was just constantly equipping and gearing up your soldiers for ground combat. However, Games Workshop released small Flying Units to table top when Soulstorm was in development and demanded each faction get a single flying unit as an advertisement for what you could experience if you played with plastic crack on tabletop. The flying units pretty much negate 95% of the games diversity and it just devolves into sneaking flying units around to execute your opponent. Yeah you can "try" to bunker up, but now you have to build all your turrets inside your base instead of building outposts to hold resource nodes, or creating choke points you can out maneuver. Additionally, its ONE singular flying unit per faction. Theres no new buildings or defenses, there isnt a wide variety of flying units. Each faction gets their 1 flying unit and thats it. So spam that 1 unit away. Isnt it fun to only use one unit in a Real Time Strategy game, and everyone practically gets the SAME unit so all these diverse factions are now defined by ONE unit being spammed. Great design choice.

Lastly, multiplayer was dead on arrival as Necrons had balance issues for a long time. But when Soulstorm dropped, Imperial Guard were god tier. IG infantry could drop space marines and necrons like it was a cakewalk. Grenade launchers and artillery pieces pretty much locked down every faction like it was nothing, add in flying units and pretty much just cover your face because a beating is coming. The new factions were awful, sisters of battle were designed to be a close range moral breaking faction that did neither very well. They didnt have the health to back them up and having to run at grenade launchers and arty spam while trying to fight planes doesnt work well for the nuns with guns. The Dark Eldar I saw as just completely useless, I could never figure out what they were supposed to be good at. I think they were terror hit and run tactics, but they pretty much died where ever they go. They have none of the advantages of Eldar (who can turn invisible and drop people from range) and just overall a disappointing faction to play.

My last gripe was the models. In dawn of war and winter assault, everything looked like it fit together. The models look good on the maps, and the new Imperial Guard fit in perfect with the old model design. Dark Crusade, the new models like the tau and necrons certainly pushed that line, but everything looked great together and the immersion was great. Then in Soulstorm, the Sisters of Battle and the Dark Eldar had 100x the animations and detail that made them look like overproduced modded factions next to the models of the older titles. They stood out like a sore thumb and funny enough made the game look even worse than before. The space marines seemed low res and outdated, the imperial guard seemed stiff and blocky, even the necrons and tau couldnt hold a torch to these new factions. Then you throw either of these factions on the new horrible maps, and its just a mess.

If you read this long ass review, again I do recommend this game. But please find mods to play with it. Unification Wars is a colossal project that while still plagued by balance issues is a much more fun 40k sandbox experience. But theres a wide variety of mods that do fix a lot of this crap in the game (my favorite being all the mods that REMOVE garbage flying units.)

You know, I thought this game might be tedious and exhaust me after a few hours.

But then I was still awake the next day playing the same game I was the afternoon before, filling the star system with Necrons, listening to the same "Berserk Skeleton Meme 10 hours" video. On loop.

I thought there would be a lot of things I was hoping to see (more units maybe) which I would miss out on in this game and that this was just a tiny step in the 40k universe. It still is a tiny step, but, as far as places to take steps go, I can't think of how this could be better! Its like the Verdun (the game) of RTS games, in that the graphics initially make you go: "Hm..." but as you play, you realize that what you're playing is game industry foundation material. This game has been as close to a perfect experience as I could have hoped for.

Edit 1: My favorite RTS ever, get The Unification Mod (Core Files + New Races + Patch + the mod installer for Unification), and you HAVE to play Ultimate Apocalypse, maybe before Unification, because I couldn't get them running together very well, something about the Tyranids not having valid effects.

The last expansion to the first Dawn of War series, this game offers you a sandbox mode, where you get to choose one of 9 races and try to conquer the solar system. The more you conquer the more requisition you get for your next attack.

Gameplay is still the same, build up base, amass army and take out the enemy. Faction capitals requiring a bit more nuanced approach, though.

You can exterminate everyone you want as anyone you want, so this is a pretty varied experience. Downside is still that controlling armies is a hassle and the unit cap cant let you go crazy. Some technical issues due to its age are also prevalent.

6.5/10

Read my other DoW reviews but to recap, DoW is dying due to lack of developer support and repetitiveness. Soul storm acts as the definitive version of DoW. While the campaign is actually hot garbage and just lazy spin of Dark Crusade, Soulstorm balances the entire game to near perfection (Necrons still are crazy) and the multiplayer while scarce is extremely fun. Soulstorm also adds Dark Eldar and Adeptus Soriatus, both factions I don‚Äôt personally care for even though I‚Äôm a 40k fan, but they are a nice edition. The modding for this game is incredible supporting both Unification and Apocalypse (Two mods I highly reccomend) If you were to get DoW I would highly recommend you pick this up whether it son sale or not.

This is my favourite of the Dawn of War series. Lots of battle maps. Lots of factions. Lots of units.

Absolutely, positively based.
No other strategy game I've played has as much of a trench warfare feel as this game.  The emphasis on zone control makes for excellent gameplay and avoids the monotony of some RTS games where it is very easy to just rush the enemy base.  The unit rosters of each faction are unique and interesting, allowing for lots of different strategies and forcing you to mix up your tactics according to which faction you are facing.  The very best troops are hard to get and usually only come out in long, even matches, but serve well to break up the stalemate.  The voice acting and visual effects are great and iconic, especially considering how old this game is.  The campaigns for the base game and for Dawn of War: Winter Assault are better than the Dawn of War: Soulstorm campaign, but in all honesty, the only correct way to play Dawn of War is to buy all the expansions, so that shouldn't be a problem.

Same as previous expansions this one includes 2 new factions, a new unit class and a global map that involves 4 planets and their moons. This time there are no faction intros, just a single intro for everyone in the conflict. I prefer this one to the Dark Crusade cause of the increase in factions and their endings and also the way they put designated webways or portals on certain territories so you can bottleneck areas of entry on your planet once you conquer it. There will be a lot of defending during the campaign since you have a lot of territories and only 1 army. Depending on the difficulty the enemy will either barely conquer anything or actually expand its territories. Still, this game is the complete package for the original Dawn of War. You have all the main factions present here and all their units and new unit types. The global map adds replay value and gives you an opportunity to win with any faction you desire. 
Highly recommended to any RTS fan or 40k fan.

Multiplayer now Gamespy free! (Steamworks)
(Single player review) Every species and faction from the previous Dawn of War main game + Expansions, with two new factions and a campaign that is almost a copy of Dark Crusade. Which is a good thing, considering how much fun Dark Crusade was with the added burden of choices and a persistent battlefield. 
The two new factions possess enough uniqueness to make them viable alternatives to the series mainstays. I've personally come to prefer the Sisters of Battle over Chaos due to the Sister's faith mechanic, where faith serves as a resource for various units to use for healing and attack bonuses in addition to whatever normal abilities the units possess. The Sisters also have a much greater reliance on melee and flame-based weapons compared to many of the other factions. I personally have no interest in the Dark Eldar, but the new faction's soul-harvesting mechanic dosen't sound like anything the other factions have.
My only real complaint agianst Soulstorm is that the additions to the single player campain seem poorly planed. Firstly, there's very little in the way of additions from Dark Crusade, but this isn't automatically a bad thing. What is troublesome, however, is that the main change, a move from a single planet battlefield to multiple, dosen't allow for zoom or any perspective changes. This means you may encounter difficulty seeing areas of the main battle map, where you view your territories and the territories of your enemies, at higher resolutions. Some tactical planning may be hampered by this, but this is not a large complaint.
If you have any interest in 40k, or if you are tired of Dark Crusade, or even if you just want to see a mostly-female (not all female, for some reason) human faction (I can't tell when it comes to the Eldar, but I guess they're female, too), pick up this game.  You don't need the other Dawn of War 1 games unless you really like space marine (Dawn of War base game) or Imperial Guard (Winter Assualt) plotlines. You will need the other games to unlock the other factions in multiplayer (already have all factions unlocked for any and all single player aspects).

Dawn of War Soulstorm and the Dawn of War series in general is one of the best RTS series i have ever played in my life so far,  it is without a doubt in my top 10 strategy games of all time list. The graphics may be a bit outdated by today's standards but the gameplay is still stunningly beautiful, fun, and bloody. The story line is also great and immersive. The most unique thing about the Dawn of War series is the fact that it has Sync-kills (or killing animations) for many individual units, even guardsmen and fire warriors who suck in melee! When you are finally bored of the game or when you have finished all the campaigns there is a TON of mods which you can install from ModDB like the Unification Mod, The Crucible, and Titanium Wars mods. I also forgot to mention that this is to this day the best Warhammer 40k RTS video game to come out in the last two decades. I hope we get Dawn of War 3 before i die. Update: Dawn of War 3 was a huge disappointment, good job Relic for not taking in the fans feedback.

I'm using Windows 10. The game is not entirely compatible with widescreen aspect ratios, and you will find yourself extremely zoomed in, compared with how these games used to play on 4:3 monitors. There is a fix! I installed this mod https://www.moddb.com/games/dawn-of-war-soulstorm/addons/camera-mod-for-dow/ which starts at a distance that matches the 4:3 gameplay, but also allows further zooming out (the view is obstructed by atmospheric mist effect, so it's not totally OP to do this). Some HUD elements are also stretched for widescreen, but nothing too horrific.

Crashes - playing the campaign, when you defeat a stronghold, the game will crash. The solution is to save the game part way through the level, exit to the top menu, reload save. It will be fixed. There is no auto-save, and some other crashes, so save often.

Pathing - a problem with the entire DoW1 series was squads getting tangled up in one another and getting stuck. That's probably the biggest gameplay issue of this game/series.

Otherwise, very strong classic RTS. The recorded voice lines in this series are pretty great. If you can get past the needs for modding and frequent saving, then I can recommend.

So after hundreds of battles that would make the 13th Black Crusade look like a picnic and a hundred and thirty hours of endless gunfire, I still love this game and everything that comes with it.
Sure there are some issues but I've not encountered any that has made me want to rip out my hair or uninstall the game in a fit of blind anger like some RTS have. The gameplay is very fun and it's feels very rewarding, especially when you wipe an enemy army, of course the chances of that are slim but it's still a great time. There is also a great modding community that keeps this game feeling fresh with each mod adding something different, there's little reason to avoid this game and I truly believe it's the best game of the DoW series so grab a lasgun and strap on your combat boots and get out there.

If you want the most factions to toy around with in a 40k RTS, you've come to the right place. You've got the Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, and Chaos from the original Dawn of War, you've got the Imperial Guard from Winter Assault, the Necrons and Tau from Dark Crusade, and the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar new to Soulstorm itself. That's not even getting into stuff like the Unification mod... The campaign, like Dark Crusade, doesn't work like a typical linear RTS campaign. Instead, you and the eight factions you didn't choose are trying to take territory from each other across four planets. You each take turns moving your forces to different territories to attack and defend, with most territorial battles being what amount to skirmish games. The exception is strongholds, which, as the name suggests, are very heavily defended and will each take the better part of an hour to conquer AT LEAST without speedrun-esque shenanigans. 

Each stronghold has a few gimmicks up its sleeve, like the SPESS MEHREENS having a bunch of beacons to call down drop pods for defensive strikes or the Imperial Guard constantly sending convoys of Baneblade parts that will lead to a super-tank very quickly knocking on your door if you don't stop them (among way too many other things... yeah fuck the IG stronghold in particular.) Each faction has a unique power to aid in their conquests, with you getting the other factions' powers when you take their stronghold (To give an example, the Sisters of Battle can establish forward bases, essentially letting you get a head start on your base building at the start of a mission, while Orks can have their territories start to garrison themselves for free.)

Haven't tried the multiplayer yet, but from the videos I've seen there is a decent variety of strategies to go for depending on factions and map. You also get to make your own custom color schemes for your armies, a nice way of acknowledging 40k's origins as a tabletop wargame.

Easily the best DoW game that's been made. 9 factions. Good everything.

So with this one its added some aircraft vehicles, and the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar.  I really love the Sisters, they're badass, easy to play, and their lines are delightfully hammy, with an awesome theme music.  The Dark Eldar, I didn't like their aesthetics so much and they had poor anti vehicle options. 

Now the Campaign here was a little bit of a downer, since its now set on four planets, unevenly dividing up the 9 playable races, so there's lots of dull back and forth between just two races on 3/4 of the planets.  They should have just did three planets so the 9 races would be evenly divided.  Also, the terrirtories are all just Annihilate or Take and Hold Critical Locations, they don't have creative different ways to win like Dark Crusade did.  But now, each race has a special bonus that you can get once you elminate their stronghold, and that is a nice touch.

I hit that "recommend" button so hard, that the Valve servers trembled a bit.

Us old RTS farts will normally refer to Starcraft 1 as "Brood War", which is the expansion name, to make clear that it doesn't make sense to play the game without the expansion. I believe the exact same should apply to "Dawn of War 1", it should be called "Soulstorm" instead. Because Soulstorm is a completely different animal.

The thing is, now after playing it, I realize Soulstorm is one of the best games of all time. Certainly the best Warhammer 40K videogame ever made.

Sounds like an exaggerated thing to say, right? But I think I am not alone. Just do a search for the Warhammer 40K tag in the Steam charts. See, first of all, just how many W40K games there are, and how many players each game has, and see how this game from 2008 is still at the top of the chart.

If we need to get still into more details, the levels of ambition in this game are off the charts: 4x style campaign mode, now with multiple planets, they added flying vehicles, and why not throw in yet another two factions with more unique mechanics, for an unheard-of 9 factions total. And yes, this means that the campaign narrative covers the combinations of you eliminating any of the other 8 factions, while playing as any of the 9 factions that are available.

I understand that people would like there to be a remaster of this game, but to me that seems an insurmountable task. This game, like Forged Alliance, is a great use case for Proton (in which it runs great) and game preservation. Because, let's be real, there will never again be a group of developers so crazy, with so much money and free time, to make a game like this (or Forged Alliance).

Anyway, works out of the box with all the FPS you need and more. The graphics can be improved nowadays, but keep in mind it's a game from 2008.

With that out of the way, let's talk about what this game is all about: cooking. One of our shiny new factions, the sisters of battle, will take you by the hand, as you learn new and exciting recipes. Ask our sister prior about her roasted ork. Inferno pistol will make wonders for cooking rare Eldar. Learn some new ways to flamb√© T'au with the help of the Immolator, our shiny new kitchen appliance. Team up with the sisters repentia and the penitent engine, to learn the secrets of thin, rare dark Eldar cuts.

Enjoy your meal!

Additionally, the definite domain "chronicles" are back, giving every situation map a smidgen of additional character.

The option of airplane is intriguing however adds a tentatively low measure of measurement to the game. Airplane are simply unendingly "jetpacking" vehicles. The two new races, the Sisters of Battle and Dark Eldar, are genuinely unmistakable. Players new to the arrangement ought to likewise feel genuinely great, however I suggest playing the past games* and making the most of their separate commitments to the arrangement prior to putting $39.99 in Soulstorm.

This game and subsequent series is pretty much the most I've played any RTS series. Soulstorm specifically has:

Pros
- Lotsa gameplay hours in campaign, skirmish, and multiplayer. 9 races that all play differently from each other with their own campaign starts makes an intensly replayable campaign.
- Skirmish/multiplayer are highly customizable, thanks to cosmetic changes in a suprisingly in depth army painter with even a way to add custom badges and banners (only downside is that if someone can throw in a hail hortler, they will invariably throw a hail hortler. You may see a few badges or banners you won't like), and gameplay ones with varying maps in size and theme, as well as changeable win conditions, team fights, etc.
- Gameplay is fun and is fairly tutorialized, so learning isn't hard at any speed. 
- The modding scene is somewhat famous as well as active, with every sort of overhaul and total conversion one can think of.
- due to being an old game, it runs fairly well on even low end machines. The artstyle is also good enough that the lack of fidelity can be forgiven

Cons:
- Of all the dow 1 campaigns, this is deffo the weakest. The RISK style campaign map doesn't really lend itself to good characterization, but Dark Crusade had character in spades. The map in Soulstorm is certainly bigger in Soulstorm, but certainly not better than Dark Crusade's. To further the RISK analogy, every planet is Australia, which makes planet hopping a royal pain in the ass to make planetfall on other parts of the Karuva system, so the only sensible thing to do is to turtle and build up forces for planetfall, making it rather boring, in comparison to Dark Crusade's smaller but far more dynamic campaign map.
- there are 9 races, but they are not made equal. Orks are considered by the community to be the weaker ones, space marines are cosidered passable at everything but great at nothing, Imperial guard are defensive masters, Necrons hit like a UPS truck but they manuver as gracefully as one, etc. Now this would be okay, with every race having strengths and weaknesses, if the eldar weren't *fuggin busted*. People back in the day had said that Relic were a bunch of eldar fanboys, and given this and other depictions of the eldar, I'm inclined to believe them. Fleet of foot still continues to dominate multiplayer with people playing eldar the way the orks were meant to play as, a massive death horde on rocket skates, but now you can't even really damage them. There is no bad way to play the Eldar, and it shows.
- depending on who you ask, this could be a plus. The amount of tech (in the Smash bros melee sense) in this game is deceptively large. You will get your butt curb stomped by strats that have been honed for nearing 2 decades now in the multiplayer. Good news is that they are not exactly hard to get due to most of them being down to squad composition, like space marine's high damage option being equipped with heavy bolters and stealthed scouts with plasma guns, and spamming the comissar's execute ability for a never ending damage and morale boost.

All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. Even with it's age, it's still very good.

The races are slightly imbalanced, however, on a big map with four plus players, this game becomes more intense as a strategy than any fast paced shooter. You micromanage like crazy, biuld units, attack, retreat ,upgrade , capture, hold, lose, take back, scout, use abilities (a mind blowing amount of them too)... And then an epic battle happens with giant Relic units and dozens of different troops and troop types. Even though DoW2 is better in physics and engine and etc. it does not have the same drive as this game... Speaking of Single player, Dark Crusade is probably the best, however for more in-depth experience I prefer the winter assault, although it is more linear.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
This is truly a masterpiece of the strategy gaming world. Even if you are not really into Warhammer World but dig good strategies, you'll probably love this game. 

[h1]More read[/h1]
The immersive world of Warhammer 40k recreated in this game is definitely exciting and after playing Soulstorm you'll probably become a fan of Warhammer 40k. The multiplayer is not dead yet and you can play with other players still or set up your own session to play with friends or some randoms. I haven't encountered any cheaters during my playtime.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Given the fact it's from 2008, optimization and performance are subpar, I haven't crashed during most of my plays however if you play the multiplayer, startup bugs might occur, which abrupt a game session for some of the people in the lobby or even for all.

[h1]Mods[/h1]
Fps is capped. Image itself with the fonts doesn't scale to the modern resolutions - you [b]must[/b] tweak this yourself via mods and various tweaks.

[b]HEADS UP:[/b] 
[url=https://www.moddb.com/games/dawn-of-war-soulstorm/addons/camera-mod-for-dow] "Better Camera Mod for DoW" [/url] is essential. 

[url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-mod] "The Ultimate Apocalypse Mod(UA)" [/url] must be mentioned as well. This is the ultimate enhancement of the base game, which effectively adds an enormous amount of new content from the community to the game: new races, new units, new modes, unlimited armies, and the list goes on.

Personally, I believe it could be fully appreciated only if you have already been playing the base game long enough.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
I do recommend buying only Soulstorm because it is the most complete and is essentially the ultimate installment of Dawn of War 1 game series.

The resources in this game are infinite which simply means the game drags on way longer than it should, and having to upgrade each individual unit means you will be babysitting one army the vast majority of the time, so multitasking around the map is extremely limited. 
If you are looking for a fun to play RTS game, then this is not the place to be unfortunately, the clunky units and simplified resources system will disappoint both players who like to micro or macro.

After diving 36 hours into Dawn of War Soulstorm, I can freely say I love this game in all its glory. This game made me love the Warhammer 40k universe, and it made me want to buy the figurines for the tabletop game ( I currently own the Necron Warriors and Space Marines as of writing this.) However, there is a major problem I have with this game, and it is with the multiplayer. Me and my friend both got the Dawn of War Master Collection for Christmas, and we were dying to play with each other in Multiplayer. But after a couple of days, we realized that the Multiplayer wasn't all that great. Gameplay and such aside, the problem we're facing is us trying to get into a game. Before we even get into a game, we either talk or do our own thing for 5-6 minutes only for the game to tell us that a Sync Error has occured. As of right now, we don't know how to fix it. We tried looking it up, using specific races or maps, hell I went to his house to try to get into a game, but it kept on giving us problems. I understand that this game is very old and it's multiplayer is not that great compared to modern day, but it ruined our excitment for the game.

THE WARHAMMER 40k GAME THAT STILL ROCKS IN 2021

Ok, I may be a bit biased as I do play the actual tabletop games.  But I will try to be as objective as possible.

I have played all 3 Dawn of War Games. I did not play the others as I have Soul Storm, as I feel this is what the other games should have been, unfortunatley Relic has deviated from the successful formula.  Soul Storm focus' mainly on building up your base, your forces, then going out to capture/contest objective points against enemy teams. While it has some research and economy elements, the focus is really more on combat and capturing points around the map. Depending on your faction , you will have different units suited to this task. Space marines are generally the most balanced, with Imperial Guard and Orks relying on vast amounts of units to fight their battles. Vehicles are also a available, and some factions vehicles really shines more against others. 

The Campaign is not bad, with a small backstory on the Kauruva subsystem. A warpstorm has overtaken the system and all the factions caught within are now engaged in a deathmatch against one another. I wont go into details about all the factions, but they got most of them portrayed correctly as far as I know (though they were missing a few from the universe, but thats ok) . The game has you taking parts of plants to conquer through small skirmishes , and grants you bonuses depending on which continents you have captured. The average play through I had was at least 10 hours per faction , which is nice as there is a lot of replayability. 

The base game is fun enough to give you lots of play-time , but the mods! Oh they really change the way the game plays, and it feels even more like Warhammer 40k! I especially enjoy the Ultimate Apocalypse and Unification mods the best. They add a ton of units to existing factions, and add new factions and subfactions. I.e Adeptus Mechanicus and Black Templars. You will have to do some downloading off steam , I got mine off ModDB, but its totally worth it if you have invested as much time as I have.

Just note, once you install these mods, they will increase the Unit capacity in-game, so likewise, will also increase system capacity. The System requirements listed will probably not be enough, but that shouldn't be a problem even with a low-end modern day computer. I'm running mine on an old FX 8370 with a gtx 770, and its usually fine, though it does stutter when hundreds of units are on screen fighting each other.

If you are a 40k fan, you must do yourself a favour and get this game. Even not on sale, its very affordable, more so that it would cost you a standard box of miniatures!

An absolutely fantastic RTS in one of the most expansive Sci-Fi settings ever developed.  Dawn of War does a remarkable job at retaining the base building aspect that I personally enjoy in RTS games while emphasizing the visceral, over the top combat of 40K.  The skirmish AI is sufficient to challenge me and getting into a coop game with one of my best friends to stomp the AI is a joy.  The graphics are good enough, but what really shines is when units clash in melee.  There's really nothing quite like watching a group of tactical marines whip out their combat knives and start dueling with Orks, or a dreadnought stomp his way into a melee, pick up the nearest enemy and squeeze before flinging the body away.

You know, I understand this is not as good as let's say Dark Crusade right, BUT...big BUTT here. This is a great game still. I remember when I bought Soulstorm as soon as it released on CD..hehe CD. I sound old now. I had the shiny new box with the purple casing and the beautiful purple CD that it came with. Loading it into my computer hoping my computer CD drive laser was not burned out enough to read the CD. It is a past time relaxing game for me. 

It is solid, has base building unlike the mistake of the Emperor Successor to Dawn of War 2 the [THRICE PURGED] that was supposed bring back Dawn of War. This game I still play and stream, sometimes with friends. I rage when I lose and I cry when sisters of battle burn my buildings with fire. It is with the love of fire, so I am satisfied with the destruction. The modding community has been a wonderful benefit in keeping this game alive. The developers had released the tools for the community to really improve the longevity of this work of art.

The game is neat in conception and you can tell where the developer's minds were at in production. Very few bugs, but most of the issues with this game is pathing, but I mean I could get over that for sync kill animations and voice overs. Ultimate Apocalypse Mod is probably the best mod for this game because Titans and Reavers are cool. 

My motto is "if you like Tonka Trucks" you'll love Ultimate Apocalypse Mod. The game really shines in squad base combat and managing your squads morale and setup against different factions. So, really knowing what to gear up against is going lose or win you that first battle. In this game, if you lose the first fight over your initial capture points, it is difficult to come back but possible. I just wish units would level up in this game and gain veterancy and be able to be upgraded to Sternguard or Exarchs at some point either during the match. Just my take on it.

The Entirety of Dawn of War RTS series brought me into this universe, and Gabriel Angelos is hopefully my Father. We don't mention the Commander of the Campaign for Soulstorm. His name is [Twice Redacted] and creates BOREALUM! 

-Just look at my hours. I could be doing something else but Speese Muhrines!
x-Soulstorms Campaign removed your ability to setup defenses for territories you conquered previously in Campaign mode. Big series minues here
-Spiffy RTS with squad based elements and moral implementation. You must always be aware of what your going against and what weapons the enemy is using against your forces. Morale no matter what weapon will kill your army no matter how strong. ***Unless you have a squad with no morale factor and those are far and few between.
-The story for the whole Dawn of War Series up to Dawn of War 2 is apart of Cannon! Awesome.
-Graphics are dates but its doable because of the quality in this series
x-Base game Sisters of Battle/Dark Eldar are a bit OP but can be dealt with if you focus on rushing commanders and anti tank units first.
-Downside is Skirmish AI up to difficulty Harder seems to die when it checks if you are stronger than it. The AI literally gives up and dies if you have more resources or units than them.
-This game actually provides actual AI difficulty. Yes, the AI starts out with more resources in Skirmish but the AI will literally beat you into the ground if you let it. Especially at insane difficulty. It is pure AI being smarter with no actual bonus rate bonuses to the AI on any difficulty. They just start out with more resources no more than 1200 requisition/ 400 power max.
-If you are still reading this I must have made this somewhat interesting to a degree and I am beyond surprised I was able ot keep your attention through this wonderful wall of text.
-Maybe if I encourage you to get the game that is good enough? Maybe, probably, who knows but just do not youtube Borealum! 
-Yes, your still here obviously and that means you should probably buy the game now.
-Multiplayer is sort of active in this game. Sort of...you needs mods to pickup the multiplayer community.
-Ok, I am done seriously talking for now. Give it a try, do not I remind you go past purchasing DOW2 that [Clearance Not Sufficient] abomination of the Emperor to mention would make the Choas gods cry in their tombs!

Yes, the entire DoW 1 series is good (and the DoW 2 series as well, although it's a completely different beast from 1).  Soulstorm isn't as good as its predecessor Dark Crusade.  It didn't improve much on its gameplay other than adding 2 new races and the "air" class of units which made little impact on the game.  What it did bring is a whole new set of campaigns for each race without drastically ruining any part of gameplay.

I strongly recommend playing Dark Crusade first, and if you finish those campaigns and crave more absolutely go for Soulstorm.  These two were the pinnacle of the DoW 1 series gameplay.  DoW 2 is great but a different style of game altogether.

I only have 42 hours at the time of this review, and I absolutely love this rts, its probably my favorite one right now. It still has a community and is better than most modern rts', I only have a couple of complaints, but those are really petty, 1 example would be the hotkeys, the default hot keys are horrid, and to change them you have to go into the files to change them. My other complaint, is the camera is really small, but this can be fixed really easily, you can just download a camera mod which fixes the problem. Overall, I love this game, its just great, its worth much more than its price to me. Not only that, you don't have to get the other expansions to unlock the other factions, you can just use the Race-Unlocker, which worked for me and a couple friends who have the game. Great game, must get.

Edit: There is a camera mod which widens the camera view, its great, get it. There is also a mod called "SSStats", since the in game stats are broken, this is really helpful. It also introduces a "ranked" mode sort of. Your MMR(score) changes depending on how many 1v1s and team games you win. You can also see a leader board if you go to their website.

Edit 2: Still a great game.

It's a real shame that they've squandered this in later games.

Even if Games Workshop doesn't like that Fans exist that do more than give them money, I highly recommend this game if you already played any other DoW title, if this is your first then I would still say go for it because its worth it, but if you get easily overhelmed, Dark Crusade has less features and feels more like a "beta" to this game in a sense.

After about 90 hours of playing this game, I have literally nothing to say about vanilla DoWSS, as I have exclusively and extensively toiled in mods, and as such this review is going to be covering some of the larger ones. Unification and Ultimate Apocalypse are two very big ones that I've spent a surplus of time in. Unification is good for what I'd describe as roughly recreating a 2000 point battle, It doesn't have the grand scale or godlike units of Ultimate Apocalypse, but I'd say that is a pro or con, depending on your preference. Unification is balanced fairly well for a mod, Ultimate Apocalypse is not. UA is a massive scale battle set in practically apocalypse rules, the only issue at the moment is the same issue that plagued Epic, and that is lack of dedicated xenos titans that can match an Imperator, now obviously you won't be seeing the Imperator often, but it can singlehandedly change the tide of the game. However, this isn't an issue the developers can ever fix, as it would be homebrew for them to make any xenos have titans that large, as it just doesn't exist in lore yet (plus most appearances of Imperators occur during the HH anyways, so no xenos were really a thought). Basically, game is okay, mods are better, that is all

If my playtime is not enough to convince you, read on:

I used to own this game and all the expansions way back when so my playtime is at least double what's listed here. This is by far the best sci fi base building RTS you will find. Tons of factions, game modes, maps, and the campaign isn't necessarily half bad (well soulstorm's is the weakest). I play this game nearly every day, and largely solo on Skirmish mode vs AI, and till now I find I am given a challenge. 

For solo skirmish players, you will start off going up against easy AI, and slowly increase to Insane, and once you reach Insane you will eventually switch to Quickstart start mode instead of standard. There are a variety of interesting win conditions like control the most points on the map, assassinate the commander, or amassing resources, destroy all HQ buildings, or destroy all unit production buildings which you can toggle at will. 

If you're here for the online aspect, don't bother unless you play private with all your friends. The entire community are wizened ancients who hate "NOOBS" and are self proclaimed gods, who have been playing for years on end and expect everyone else to get on their level.  There are a few helpful individuals and it is wonderful to see them, but a large majority are downright awful and not welcoming. 

Wait to get the Master Collection on sale (and this game goes on sale plenty for Sega sales, Warhammer sales, and the usual steam sale periods) and you will not regret it.

This experience is based on vanilla, and you should really get Dark Crusade instead if you've never played DOW 1 before (or Winter Assault, or the original game...)

Honestly, I'm only really playing it because other friends have returned to it and wish to play matches with me.

It's not a *bad* game, really.  It just feels a lot more barebones in terms of overall territories and content when compared to Dark Crusade, and the story is heavily nerfed compared to both Dark Crusade and the far more thrilling tales in the original Dawn of War and Winter Assault.  Winter Assault's story was especially memorable so, if that's your thing, get that one.

But Soulstorm added a few more gimmicks in terms of factions, and I suppose it feels more impressive lorewise to take over multiple tiny planets instead of one large one like in Dark Crusade.  Each of the factions from previous games are here, and the game does have blurbs when each faction's stronghold is overrun, unique to the specific faction that overran it.  The Dark Eldar pillaging Nan Yanoi has a different blurb compared to the forces of Chaos achieving the same feat, for example.

But if you're reading this, stahp.  Just get the mods, apparently, or for pure vanilla experiences I really loved Dark Crusade...  But despite the hiccups on release one can't really say this is a bad game.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
I can only barely recommend this game. If not for the fact that it has 2 new races which offer some cool playstyles then this would be a hard pass. While Soulstorm withour modifications has some problems in campaign, playing Bugfix mod merged with Persistant Bases will make for an adequate experience similar to Dark Crusade, but with more races and more challenge. Use DoW Mod Manager to merge the above mentioned mods and you are set.

[h1]Description[/h1]
Dawn of War Soulstorm is the last add-on to the game, featuring another meta-campaign like in Dark Crusade, but now with some more meta-progression mechanics and 2 new races. It also adds a light attack flying vehicle for each existing race. I'll try to go over changes and additions:

Sisters of Battle - You could think of them as female Space Marines (although in the lore the differences are huge). They are basically space warrior-nuns who love cleansing enemies with flames. Their basic playstyle is based on utilizing flamers to burn morale of the oponnent. Some enemies are more resistant to this tactic, that's why they also have access to Acts of Faith. Lvl 1 tech aAct can heal your squad, lvl 2 gives all squad's weapons ability to ignore armor of the enemy (flamers can destroy light tanks in seconds!) and lvl 3 will place a buff that damages any enemy who hurts the unit. Even though Sisters feel a lot like Space Marines at first - their focus on breaking morale and using Acts of Faith as well as their very unique vehicles make them much different to play in practice. Did I mention that they have an artilery that's shaped like church organs and their ultimate unit is a literal Angel who kills people with a giant sword? If that doesn't make you want to play them - what's wrong with you.

Dark Eldar - I gotta be honest - out of all new races I like them the least and simply didn't feel like playing them after a marathon completing every single DoW game. They are similar to normal Eldar, but even more focused on quickness and ranged weapons with some really annoying global spells. That does not mean at all that their addition is boring or unnecessary - the very fact that we get 2 more races in this update is great as it introduces more stuff for you to try and fight against.

Campaign buildings - In Dark Crusade if you built something during a mission and won - the buildings would stay if the territory is ever attacked. That's not the case in Soulstorm. It makes the game very tedious when each time your territory is attacked you have to start building and capturing points from scratch. You can still buy buildings on the strategy map, but doing that for each territory slows the game even more, plus, you'd still need to capture strategic points every time. This can be fixed with Persistent Bases mod, which I recommend doing.

Race bonuses - In Dark Crusade there were several territories that granted access to special abilities like moving twice during a turn and the like. This time each race has access to one such bonus, and you can gain acces to them as you defeat the home territory of each race. I think that this approach is better since it makes it much more rewarding to kill the enemy race off, but some bonuses are much better than others. For example Sisters start with the ability to buy buildings for an attack, which is by every metric the strongest one. Compare this to Tau's orbital cannon that is supposed to soften up defences as you attack, but in practice I never noticed it having ANY effect at all.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ More races[/b]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Slogfest: no persistant bases[/b]
[b]- Slogfest: AI multiple bases[/b]
[b]- Idiotic plot[/b]
[b]- Unstable[/b]

More about pros and cons below.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ More races[/b]
Both Sisters of Battle and the Dark Eldar give a huge increase to the game's replayability and the sheer amount of stuff that is in this game after 3 expansions is impressive.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Slogfest: no persistant bases[/b]
If playing unmodded - you won't have your structures persist in between missions on the same map. Have you finished a map, slowly creeping the enemy out and building out your defences and multiple bases? Well, guess what - if the AI decides to attack that province you will start from ZERO. Dark Crusade expansion had your buildings always persist as long as you win, here the mechanics slow down the campaign immensly. This is the biggest issue, thankfully possible to fix with a mod. 

[b]- Slogfest: AI multiple bases[/b]
After a few turns (and on the webway nodes) you will always face an enemy defensive force consisting of 2 large bases. This means you will have to attack with little to no Honor Guard into an already established enemy force. This pretty much forces you to play cheesy rush tactics to get at least one of the enemy strongholds off the face of the map and with how AI loves to micro around and build up random production buildings everywhere - you will need to constantly scout every strategic point and make sure that they don't rebuild. If you don't do that - you will soon drown in an insane amount of tier 3 units. I can't count how many times have I slowly started losing because my army was busy destroying some outlying bases while the other enemy launched a full-scale attack on my production facilities. This forced me to go back only to get sandwitched by 2 armies and after defeating both the time to rebuild my losses only let the enemies build up more remote bases everywhere and quickly pump out more and more fucking tanks. I hate it. I HATE IT. It's not difficult, it just makes you play the same rush strategy every game, which isn't fun when you have to do this for EVERY territory on the map.

[b]- Idiotic plot[/b]
The main Imperial Guard base pumping out Baneblades like there's no tomorrow and METAL BAWXES are both huge memes among the DoW1 community. The first time Space Marines and Imperial Guard had to fight each other was already endearing, but now they fight again? And this time Sisters of Battle fight them both too? For those, who don't know - Space Marines, Imperial Guard and Sisters of Battle are all part of the same Imperium and for the most part they should not work against each other.

[b]- Unstable[/b]
This game has a problem where it can freeze while loading after beating a stronghold mission. Bugfix mod seems to fix it, though I've had 2 crashes throughout my playthrough and I couldn't be bothered after the second one which happened after a stronghold mission.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
Honestly if you are already deep enough to consider buying this game after playing the previous ones then just buy it. It may be worse by design, but it adds enough new stuff to be compelling.

I can recommend 3 mods that may improve your experience with the game.

Persistant bases + bugfix (merge them together using DoW Mod Manager) - will fix most problems with the game, while keeping it as vanilla as possible. I've had a pathfinding/units blocking on geometry problem with this setup, but reinstalling solved it.

Unification - modifies some of the game's units and adds some on top of that, also adds some new mechanics with ability to customize some of them. Lastly it adds Tyranids to skirmish. If you already played each race in Dark Crusade and want to replay them in Soulstorm then this mod will add some freshness. One big problem in it is how sound mixing is totally broken and some sound FX will be much louder than they should be.

Apocalypse - multiplayer/skirmish mod that increases the scale of the game and adds many new units and variants - including huge superweapons. This mod is ridiculous and IMO the game's engine can't handle what it tries to achieve, especially with it's terrible pathfinding. It's still an ambitious piece of content.

I'd give the base Soulstorm a 4/10, but considering the mods the score would rise up to
[h1]6/10[/h1]
Kind of cool, but also disappointing.
This is by far the most addictive game to me...after years I still play.

What is Chaos? Suffering, you might say. Oppression. Deceit. But could not all these things be said of your Imperium? You hunt down the talented and the strong-willed. You break them or sacrifice them. You lie to your citizens and wage war on those who dare speak out. The inquisitors you call masters assume guilt and execute millions on a whim. And why? Why do you do this? Because you know Chaos is there but you do not know how to fight it, so you crush your own citizens for fear that they might aid the Enemy. The Imperium suffers because of Chaos. No matter how hard you fight, that will never change. Chaos exists in a state of permanent victory over you - you dance to our tune, mortal one, you butcher and torture and repress one another because the gods of the warp require you to. The Imperium is founded on Chaos. My lord Tzeentch won your war a long, long time ago.

Definitely one of the best RTS game ever made. While the base game itself is very strong, the modding community is what keep this game alive for all these years. I can recommend 2 mods for those who with to greatly enhance their Dawn of War experience:

1. The Ultimate Apocalypse Mod. if you want the scale of battle to be much bigger with endgame weaponry, mass Titan battle and see the carnage where each unit is tossed around very easily, this mod will give you what you want. Be wary that the game time for each skirmish will become much longer though as the battle scale become much bigger and more complex.

2. Unification Mod. Play this if you want more races and more units but still want the gameplay scale to be somewhat similar to the base game. While not as complex as the Ultimate Apocalypse, this mod really improve upon the base game.

Nuns with Guns, extremely kinky space elves, the russian army in space, extremely repressed space elves, blue space communists with japanese mecha, absolutely hammy super-satanists who are so determined to be evil that they become hilarious, walking memes in power armor or mechanized coffins, robot skeletons who just got out of bed, and the horrifying offspring of shrek, the hulk, a glasgow pub crawl, and a Michael Bay movie.

Ladies, Genestealers and Gentlemen, this Warhammer 40k at its finest. An excellent, highly aggressive strategy game with great fundamentals, a solid, complex campaign that improves on Dark Crusade's already great campaign, and massive faction variety, and good build variety within that. If you've never played 40k this is arguably the best way possible to get into the setting, and if you're a 40k vet, this is one of the best games for it out there. The campaign is even better as you have to take over PLANETS this time! I mean, you have to reinforce territories you rule, but you also have to attack every turn as well, or it'll be hard to get ahead. I also recommend learning the races so as to play them better. The Tau are long range shooters; the Eldar are both agile and physically powerful; the Space Marines are physically powerful and use a lot of vehicles to back up their marines; the Sisters of Battle are a more agile version of the Space Marines; the Necrons are slow but deadly walking tanks; the Imperial Guard overwhelm with numbers; the Orks are both numerous and can out-shoot and out-fight you in groups or one-on-one; the Dark Eldar are hit-and-run tacticians; and Chaos can use their own Space Marines and daemons to overwhelm you. All in all, this game is solid on action, story (it needs a little work, but it makes sense nonetheless), and the races are all distinct as mentioned above.

Probably my favorite RTS of all Time. Keep in mind this is only if you mod it. My personal recommendations are either Ultimate Apocalypse Mod or the recent Unification Mod. 

Both will give you loads of hours of entertainment. If you like big scale battles, a lot of heavy weight units and expanded mechanics, then UA is the better choice (specially if your pc can handle it). If you instead prefer more quantity and race diversity, go for Unification Mod, which adds around 18+ races to vanilla. This doesn't mean it's lacking on quality, as all the new races have great balacing around them and are not copies of existing ones, with all of them having very unique playstyles.

Overall, if you're a 40k fan, i recommend this game wholeheartedly to you. Mod it, gets some friends and have a blast playing multiplayer and enjoying the overall chaos.

had this game for a long time before I had it on steam. while not my favorite DoW version (Dark Crusade is by far my all time favorite, in terms of balance and gameplay) I do like the factions that were added in Soulstorm. the work well, they fit, they're well constructed, and unique. that being said, in this expansion it really feels like certain factions took a big nerf from where they were in Dark Crusade (eldar), while others got a significant buff. the inclusion of air units is mostly forgettable. only a handful of the factions' air units are actually worth using and most of them are nothing more than an annoyance. still a great game though. it stands up to the test of time and is very much worth getting. it still retains its place as one of the best RTS games (imo) and certainly the current peak of the Dawn Of War franchise. one can only hope that if there is ever another one in the series that it follows from the example of DoW1 games and doesnt follow the increasing trend-following and moba-style and gameplay that DoW2 & 3 made their core.

You go to your local burger place. The food isn't great, the prices aren't too low, but it's local and it's warm. You shuffle to the counter, scan your card, and get roughly the same meal you've been ordering for the past year. Over the last few months you've made a few variations, maybe you've added some onion rings to the mix or you're trying out that blue cheese they recommended, but it's still the same burger that you know and are comfortable with.

Then, just as you're about to leave, the guy in line behind you catches your ear. He's tall, and speaks quietly, but in the ambience of that little shop him speaking and the sizzle of grills are the only thing you can hear over the sound of cars outside. You pause.

You've never heard of that burger before.

But the chef has. He nods, and calls out something to the guys in the back, and you see a grin you've never noticed before crack across the man's face. Glancing up, you see the standard menu of the joint doesn't even have the burger the guy just ordered on it. Like it was some kind of secret they didn't want just anyone to know about.

The next guy behind that orders a burger. You've known this one for a few weeks; you get off work at around the same time. He's shorter, and a little less sharp than the man before, but the light always catches him in a soft way that washes off the imperfections most people would pick out if they saw him on the street or in a club.

It's not the same burger the last guy ordered. But it's another one that you never knew existed. The guy that comes after, broad-shouldered and neatly groomed- and far too well dressed for a seedy joint off the high-street- orders the same as the guy before last. And he asks for a side that you don't even think would be served in a burger place.

And the chef just nods. He's not surprised, and barely even pays attention to the advertised menu. In the back, the fryers hiss in protest as the orders swell in number. A fourth man comes to make his order, then a fifth and a sixth. Burgers like the ones ordered before only in the sense that they're utterly unknown and barely seem possible to make in such a small shop come one after the other, each big, strong man nodding as he takes his order. Ignoring the menu, ignoring what should be possible.

You look down. In your hands is the same burger that you've been eating all your life. You always thought it was a pretty good size. But, after tonight?

It's small. It doesn't sit right in your hands. It doesn't fill someone up the way it should.

It's just.. pathetic.

You long to be like those other men. To have a piece of meat that can actually satisfy. The kind of thing that marks an alpha male, not a pathetic loser that can only dream of the life they live.

You don't deserve to be treated the same as them. No. You'll never have a burger that can satisfy again, after seeing that glorious meal the other, *real* men have. You can't hide in ignorance, or pretend it never happened. Everyone saw you with your sad, pathetic little snack of a burger on their way out.

You'll never forget the way that they looked at you. There's a burning in your chest, that you can't put your finger on. You've felt envy before, when it came to different things that you tried to compete in earnestly. But this? Maybe because it's something that you always assumed was the same for everyone, or something that you had already won effortlessly.

But.. you don't hate it. Even with how sad you are, pitying yourself only makes that burning worse.

There is a dusting of red on your cheeks. You're not sure how long it's been there, but when you blink and remember where you are the only thing that fills your mind is the stare of everyone else in the joint. The burning gets hotter, and standing there with your tiny burger surrounded by bigger packages only amplifies how weak and helpless you feel.

Very good RTS with not so small community still vividly playing it. Many Warhammer 40k factions to chose from, good graphics and sounds (especially Ork sounds are genuinely crazy!), smooth controls (not only hotkeys, but also stances for your squads - melee, ranged stance etc., which makes the game more planned and less frenetic).
Macro, micro, map control, everything is here. Slightly less economic focus and more of a composition and micro focus compared to more mainstream RTS games (like Starcraft). 
Interesting campaing concept (linear and non-linear part, non-linear is close to skirmish mode). Definitevely recommended for any strategy or Warhammer 40k enthusiasts!

While I'm leaving a positive review, I want to state clearly that this is purely for the MODDED version of the game. Whether you're using the Unification mod or Ultimate Apocalypse or any of the many exceptional mods created by fans, it'll elevate your Soulstorm experience to something incredible. However, the base game itself is a huge downgrade from Dark Crusade with its questionable balancing, weak campaign, embarrassing writing and lack of originality. Iron Lore really dropped the ball with this expansion and it's thanks to the fans that the game is enjoyable at all. Unfortunately, factions introduced by the mods like the Tyranids aren't playable in the campaign. So unless you're either focusing on multiplayer or are just content with skirmish games or maybe using the Strongholds mod to play the main campaign set pieces, there's no way to get the full value out of the amazing new content.

One of my favorite games of all times. The game has several unique factions like dark elves, elves, orks, humans. The game is from 2003 and the title 'Soulstorm' is a DLC released in 2008. This game is the most played game in the DoW-series even though its almost 20 years old. And even though there were hundreds of players playing this game every day and you could easily join games, the owners decided to take down all the multiplayer servers. So now you can't play it online anymore. However, playing this game have been an exciting journey and it finally took me the 1000 hours of gameplay to beat the hardest difficulty in the game: 'insane' difficulty. So all in all, it's been a good time and I know consider this game finished and will get to pass to the graveyard of videogames with love.

This is a real RTS, with basebuilding, fast paced squad-based combat and a large array of Units and Races to use, with each unit having unique qualities when compared to its' counterpart from other Races.
Pros:
- 9 unique races with different Commanders, Infantry and Vehicle units at your disposal
- large variety between units
- Point control system for Map control (helps the flow of battle)
- Large array of maps and a Campaign mode which is similar to Galactic Conquest from SwBf2
       - Each race has a fortress that the player must siege, with unique story lines 
- Multiplayer (not so much as of 2021)

Cons:
- Franchise did not carry on this style of gameplay into newer sequels (this is an opinion and not reflective of this game or any other in particular)

Overall Great game 9/10

ah dawn of war one of the best rts games in its year. let tell you how this game is worth every penny. unlike the new dawn of war. this puts quality over quantity. Dawn of war soulstorm puts a crap ton of content. the game has quality soundtrack which really got me pump for the game in the campaign the game lets you pick 8 differnt factions in the game which ever you choose will have thier pros and cons in their abilitys. the Ai has been improved over their previous games and the satisfication of destroying your enemy bases is still charm to this day but they are also some bad things about soulstorm and one of those thing was its bugs, lags or a few frame drops another thing was the campaign it could have improved more in my opinion. it really felt blank and a copy of dark crusade. in my opinion the campaign can improve by adding new features like more creative ideas like backstory on the faction like dark crusade did or choosing your equipment like dawn of war 2 for the heros, or going to a land that you capture and reinforcing your base in real time waiting for the next defense. but overall i thing dawn of war soulstorm is a badass game for a decent price and passible graphics my verdict for this is 9 out of 10 it is good game and i recommend any rts player thanks for reading :)

Still one of the greatest RTS games ever made, and puts many modern games to shame. True to the 40k lore and battles are chaotic, fun and fast paced with lots of tactical nuances.

Only gripe is the camera control is out dated and a pain. There is a mod that can be downloaded called ZoomModSettings and it works with both Soulstorm and Dark Crusade (you have to run the game once for the Mod to detect the installs). After that the camera behaves like any modern game using mouse wheel etc.

Once you get that Mod going you have a brilliant 40k RTS with great skirmishes and campaign to enjoy.

Buy it now!

Been playing the game since 2010 pretty much, to this point, and fairly with confidence and certainty I can assume it's one of it's kind, and to me one of the best RTS games ever created next to Dark Crusade, even though it has no further support from developers anymore. Quite frankly it lacks  optimization on high tier PCs, the limit of 2gb is not enough to support consistent gameplay, sometimes I get crashes, to some extent fps drops, but nothing to be annoyed by anyway, luckily it doesn't occur too often, its still playable. I think adding additional race of tyranids, would have improve the feeling of being around 40k even more, its one of the primary threats to all other races in 40k and fighting against that kind of hostile would give me better improved immersion around 40k(in mine humble opinion). I get it that apocalypse mod got tyranids introduced, to me it lack certain aspect which is balance, and fighting in that kind of environment would be more chaotic than entertaining. I would honestly appreciate a remake or a remaster from formal developers, I think the game needs it and deserves it.

Enough said, thanks for attention... game very much recommended.

It also has a somewhat lacking feeling on the voice acting for the main characters becuase it seems they just ported DC's voice lines to their respective races while only DE and SOB have any real character and thats not talking about the MEHTAWL BAWXES Firraveus Carron and the SPAESS MEREENS commander Boreale memes.

Multiplayer:
GOOD LUCK, there are poeple on here that are just way to good to be playing multyplayer casually, I dont know why but poeple with major skills in this game just decide to drop in matches and try as hard as they can to win even if their fighting players with essentialy no skill or comparable skill level. I understand you have to play somewhere and keep your gaming skills up and all. But theres no way to keep it up if your fighting againts people who have no clue as to get a proper build order or even a decent size army at T1.

Positive points.

Campaign:
Despite it flaws  it can actually be pretty fun if your playing any other race or even necrons and chaos and your not trying to cheese it. Otherwise its just Dark crusade's campaign with just more territorys to take over and 2 more strongholds to fight.

Multyplayer:
You need mods or friends who have the same skill level as you otherwise it can be kinda unfun or boring, mods like Ultimate apocalypse and Titanium wars are your best multiplayer mods since they add alot to the game.

Thats about it really, only thing I can recommend really is when you use mods like UA or TITS, other than that Id recommend Dark crusade instead.

TLDR yes def get it if you like warhammer or rts games. If you enjoy what you see but wish you could tweak some things, Find and install Ultimate Apocalypse 


 it is good as a base game to introduce you to not only warhammer as a whole but also as an introduction to Dawn of war. I would also say however that if you enjoy the feel of the rts then look for Ultimate Apocalypse online. its a total conversion mod that is easy to get working and really fixes all of the games issues and adds lots of new maps, 2-3 new factions, overhauls all of the games factions to make them closer to lore and a whole hell of a lot more interesting. 

for instance the imperial guard gets conscripts as a super cheap starting unit and adds two new leader units that are just as cheap, these two allow you to make builders and basic infantry wherever they are so you can spread out incredibly quickly compared to the initially slow start of the base guard which is really fitting for the lore and the other changes really make you feel like just a bunch of guys going up against the forces of hell and superhuman beings.

the space marines lower their overall numbers but makes it so one space marine can not only dish out but also take quite the beating. Making them really feel like the insanely powerful tanks of men that they are supposed to be. and many other additions to all the other races as well which would make this review way too long

I have always loved this game and still find myself returning to it time after time, years after when I first played Dawn of War.

Any 40k fan owes it to themselves to play this game if they haven't ever tried it, even if it's a little dated by now.  There are some decent mods available for it too, that really overhaul and help modernize it a bit, as well as adding more units/factions.  Even without the mods, which are a little annoying to install and have no campaign, it is definitely worth it.

While it's campaign leaves a lot to be desired compared to the excellent campaign of Dark Crusade, Soulstorm brings some much needed balance changes to fractions. The Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle can feel a bit unfinished and aerial vehicles don't seem all too interesting. Also even after years of patches, this game still tends to be very buggy.

On it's own, Soulstorm is a weak expansion to a great game. Thankfully the main gameplay is so good, it's shortcomings can be easily overlooked.

Where Soulstorm really shines and what makes it worth it, is the massive amount of fan support of mods. Lots of new units, races and the famous Ultimate Apocalypse Mod make Soulstorm probably THE Warhammer 40k game to pick up and play.  It makes an already great game even more bombastic and fleshes the W40K universe out even further.

If you are already a fan of Dawn of War 1/Dark Crusade and want to go wild with the mods, this is a strong recommendation. Without, it's not all too necessary to get.

What can I really say about this game that others haven't already said, I firmly believe it is without equal, the greatest use of the Warhammer IP that has ever been created and possibly the best strategy game ever made in it's own right.

The game has all your favourite warhammer 40k races, but if you don't know warhammer fear not, you don't really need to, all you need to know is that every race has a different playstyle, for example if you wanted to go for aggressive hit and run tactics, you'd pick the Dark Eldar with their skimmer units, if you wanted to hide away and build up a massive overwhelming force to crush your opponent you'd pick normal Eldar with their invisible buildings, if you wanted constant overwhelming numbers you'd either go for Orks if you wanted to be aggressive, or Imperial Guard for defensive play, and many more options are present too. Even within each race you have multiple strategies and ways to play the game, this is arguably one of the most in depth games in this regard even to this day.

There is a learning curve, every race has different units, different buildings, different mechanics, etc, to learn, and it can take some time to learn them all, but it is necessary, it doesn't matter if you know everything there is to know about the Tau, if you don't have a clue what your opponents units do, for example if you were against the Necrons, if you haven't played them you may not realise their units can simply get back up off the ground and continue fighting even in death, or that their headquarters building can literally fly around the map vaporising your armies, or most importantly that they only have one resource instead of 2.

Speaking of the resources, its actually rather simple, each race has either 1, 2, or 3 resources, only the necrons have 1, and that's power, every other race has power, and requisition, then the Dark Eldar also have souls, and the Sisters of Battle have faith. The only ones that really matter are power and requisition, power is simple to get, you build power generators, that's it, nothing more to it, requisition is obtained by capturing command points.

The maps in this game range from tiny, cramped 1v1 arenas, to huge, sprawling terrains for up to 8 players to wage all out war against one another, there really is something for everyone.

In short, there's a lot to love about this game and I firmly believe everyone should play it, and yes, there is still an active online community to play against too, and the game does support modern high resolutions.

Word of Warning; I have been having issues lately after purchasing a HDR monitor, if I have the HDR turned on it hugely reduces my framerate, so if you're having issues try turning off HDR to see if it solves it.
