A good game if you are a fan of the series, however there are some issues that do detract from the game.

Pros:
 - Wildly differing armies offer a great deal of variety
 - Visceral, bloody combat that is very satisfying
 - Able to field a lot of units simultaneously

Cons: 
 - SP campaign is bland, which is ironic considering the voice acting. It is almost like the writers were in a different room at all times. If you want to get a REAL experience of what the 40k universe is like, play Dawn of War and Dawn of War: Winter Assault instead.
 - Poor unit movement. Like I mentioned above, you can host large battles but dont expect your units to move in sync like Starcraft 2. Trying to coordinate foot soldiers with vehicles by their side is a nightmare, and more often than not trying to organize an effective formation (vehicles front, soldiers behind) is going to make for a hopeless mess. Which is, in turn, made worse by:
 - Maps are too small for all these units. The "huge" maps that host 8 player free for alls are better suited to 2v2s or even 1v1s

Overall, a so so game that leans more towards the 'good' side of the meter.

If you are a fan of 40k, RTS or even just this series of games you can't go wrong with Soulstorm, you will find a debate between soulstorm and dark crusade being the better game but honestly a fundemental part of purchasing soulstorm should be to download the ultimate apocalypse mod straight after.

The truth is a part of where DoW3 went wrong was having a small selection of races from a world that is 40k that has so many. The DoW series lets you add and keep races as you bought every progressive game in the series which was such a worthwhile marketing stragedy. With all the DoW games you unlock every race. 

Now why this game that will before you know it hit 20 years of age is still better than DoW3 and any future game I expect in the franchise, The 40k and modding community for this game is huge, there are at least triple the amount of races in the base game to download and play, countless new units, buildings and even reworking the campaign to include it all (I am a small but helpful part of the campaign mod team) 

I am nor a poet or a writer and can't spend the time to write a well written review to convince you to buy this game, all I can say is for it's price, replay value, mod community and so much content for an old game, any RTS or 40k fan is cheating themselves not getting this game, and the entire series.

The game on itself is not much of a departure from previous iterations besides of the addition of 2 new races with their own gimmicks; however many criticize it for the lack luster campaign and races. 

The modding scene however remedies many of people's gripes with it. 

- Ultimate Apocalypse: reflecting the freedom of tabletop and intensity of in lore battles with its large armies and titanic units. The vast customization of matches help alleviate new comers, challenge experts or form unique scenarios.
- Eternal Confrontation: an experience more similar to vanilla but expands upon it with more units, rebalances and races. Giant plus for the inclusion of the Death Korps of Krieg, Mordian Guard and Arbites.
- Ultimate Unification: adds the best of the modding scene's races and compiles them into a giant moshpit of chaos and battle. Fight with the Adeptus Mechanicus, Armageddon Steel Legion, Emperor's Children and so much more.

Conclusion: On its own, I can't fully recommend Soulstorm, that title would have to go to Dark Crusade and its amazing campaign scenarios and narrative. However, the modding scene is tremendous, easy to get into and most importantly free.

There are games that aged well and then there's Dawn of War 1. This game is ugly and outdated by any measure, Dawn of War is an assault on the senses and overall an unenjoyable game, the pathetic ai and annoying mechanics all drown out the interesting setting and decent combat design. When compared to other old RTS's like supreme commander, stronghold, or warcraft 3, dawn of war just seems pathetic in how poorly it aged. Many of the overarching design decisions did not hold up over time and its easy to understand why Relic changed up the formula so much for DoW 2 and DoW 3, while the game has a deveoted following it is in spite of its issue and mostly due to its setting rather than any particular value of the game itself.

I love the way the campaign mode plays, conquer a map, use overmap resources and upgrades to affect your in-scenario units and commander. Dawn of War 3 is nifty but I feel it pulls too far away from the RTS concepts that made this game fun. 

Pros:
-Unit composition matters, it's not just make the biggest vehicle and win
-commander units can actually sway the field of battle, though can be overpowered by a swarm of regular units
-overmap progression instead of mission based progression (more interesting to me than missions for a global conquest game)

Cons:
-cannot zoom out very far without altering the game slightly which caused my game to crash every two or three play sessions.
-Autoresolve SUCKS HORRIBLY, you will either be always playing your defensive matches, or you will be dropping to six when an A.I commander attacks your ten (fortification number) with a  freaking two
- For a game with unit composition mattering, sorting through a mass selection of troops is annoying and cumbersome.

While it has a number of obvious flaws, making it weaker than Dark Crusade, I still enjoy Soulstorm. It adds two new factions (Dark Eldar & Sisters of Battle, both of which I like very much) and various units for existing ones. 

The strongholds are generally weaker, the story is very weak and the Necrons have a lack of new content. However, these problems reflect a lack of refinement compared to previous entries, more than being a bad game.

I recommend trying either the base game or Dark Crusade before thinking about getting this. The exception is if you are not at all interested in the campaign and simply want a multiplayer RTS, in which case Soulstorm is the best simply because it has the most units and factions.

You might also want to consider watching the ThunderPsyker reviews for these games on YouTube. It will show you some footage and I agree with most of what he said.

The base game has 4 awesome, completely different races. Every battle is different because it's a different combination of races, teams, opponents, and map. The expansions added 5 more races so now the combinations are just endless. And that's what keeps you coming back to this game. 

The game is the perfect combination of micro and macro and it punishes turtling - which is why it's undisputedly the best RTS out there. Yes that's right - it's better than Starcraft, C+C, even Cannon Fodder.

Every race has awesome units and loads of interesting abilities that can turn the tide of battle. Every battle can have its tide turned back and forward multiple times if you have a good match of good players. The new flying units are a bit meh, but good to have. 

Sisters of battle are a Space Marine variant but with enough differences to make them fun in their own right. It took me 11 years to zoom in and realise that Repentia sisters are quite hot. The mek thing is one of the best units in the game.

Dark Eldar are probably the weakest race in the game, but they have some interesting quirks and can be fun to play. But the last thing you want is to get these when you go random race.  

The campaign isn't great which is a disappointment but who needs that anyway. This is multiplayer heaven, even if you just comp stomp. 

Dark Crusade is better, but this brings completion and it's the one everyone plays. DOW2 is Ok but changes the core to be more micro focused, which is fine if you like that. But this is better. And forget about DOW3, that game was so bad it killed Relic. Buy this game and see the peak of Real Time Strategy.

I only started to get into Warhammer 40k early this year (2020), and this game has proven to be a great way to begin my new obsession. The Sisters of Battle are a zealous bunch on par with the Space Marines in their devotion to the Emperor and their willingness to wipe out file xenos filth with righteous bolter fire.

If that appeals to you you'll soon find yourself chanting along their sermons as you command them to purge alien hovel after alien hovel.

The story is a bit silly, with forces loyal to the Emperor slaughtering each other for no real reason, while there's plenty of xenos to purge, but there's plenty of hammy dialogue that's birthed several memes (METAL BAWKSES!) and is very enjoyable as well. A true 40k experience.

Some aspects of the game are pretty dated (pathfinding especially) but despite that there have hardly been any RTS's that nailed it as much as this game and there have been none that managed to do this and include so many of the major 40k factions (all but Tyranids).

Great game. However, I feel Dark Crusade is much better. The campaign elements feel far worse than Dark Crusade. Honor guard costs a fortune, cutscenes are boring and stupid, and characters like Gorgutz dont have the same charm as they did before. Now, that might just be a writing issue or the fact they have a different voice actor, but it still feels terrible. If you want a good skirmish mode however, this is your game. Theres a massive amount of modifications for this game, and they're FANTASTIC. Some just add simple races such as the Tyranid mod, while others turn the game batshit insane. Ultimate Apocalypse is the mod you want if you think the base game is just too bland or you're just bored. The addition of aircraft doesnt really fit the engine or gameplay of Dawn of War, and they're just lightweight tanks that can pass over cover. Which, we already had the land speeder and I cant remember the name of the eldar tank.

All in all, the game is better with mods, but if you like games vanilla, go buy Dark Crusade instead.

Takes a lot of steps back from what was achieved in Dark Crusade with the campaign. You no longer retain bases in territories you take, you only keep the parts of your base you have paid for with requisition, which is extremely limited to only turrets, generators, and level 1 buildings. As if the game wasn't enough of a slog already with units taking a hefty amount of requisition, your base will now take a significant investment of requisition in order to be able to hold up against enemy attacks, which have occasionally spiked to 10 strength assaults despite the enemy having no territory, leaving my 3 strength base that I thought was safe completely screwed. The only solution seems to be to wait dozens of turns until you have enough requisition to invest in both units and buildings for your claimed territories, assuming no 10 strength assaults body slam you out of nowhere during the process, making the game an absolutely boring grind where you go nowhere. Also, you will rarely ever see higher level infantry/vehicles unless you purposefully delay the game in order to obtain them, but what is the point if you don't retain that on the next defense? The stronghold missions crash the game immediately upon completion, too, so you can say goodbye to 30 minutes-1 hour of gameplay unless you saved right before completing it. The game only has these issue fixed upon installing mods, but you can only use one mod at a time unless they are fused together, so you are going to have to play with some issue regardless unless you want to invest your time in fixing a game that should have had these game-breaking bugs/features in the first place. Necrons are still bull, the new Faith feature introduced with the Battle Sisters factions feels like a gimmick and doesn't fit into the gameplay too smoothly, and some of the units feel useless to the point of never even training any, especially when you consider the addition of aircraft, which can pass over all terrain, move fast, and can render training some other vehicles or infantry pointless when you can just spam aircraft at the enemy base. Really, don't get this game unless you are going to install Ultimate Apocalypse. The modders working on that treasure made this game better than a professional game studio, which makes the efforts of said studio all the more disappointing.

Been playing this game ever since it came out, it's awesome. Best 40k RTS hands down. DoW 2 and 3 are not really true sequels, it's kinda sad but what can you do. DoW 2 is passable as a separate experience, DoW 3 is a total joke. Awesome faction variety, excellent combat, not too fast-paced, not as sucky as StarCraft 2, really feels grimdark and gritty. Resource generation is its weak point since it was the incipient concept for the Company of Heroes franchise, not very complex but the rest of the game makes up for it. Has the best modding community, few games can boast such a massive modding fanbase.

Soulstorm is best Dawn of War and possibly best 40k game (that actually includes a majority of the races without having to pay for them as DLC.) Yes I KNOW Tyranids aren't in it, get over it, it's a small price to pay.

I've been playing this game for more than 10 years now on multiple PCs, I never went bored about it.

The lore is amazing, the game overall, is amazing, the graphics still look decent today, the gameplay enables multiple gemaplay styles (the snowballing humans vs the short term necrons), that represent their history and personality, lore-wise. 

Even though I feel like some lore "adjustments", were made (eldars back despite their almost destruction, the necrons back after the "Great Sleep"...), overall I feel a good level of respect of W40K's lore. 

Little mistakes: Ork with morale... Doesn't make sense, but well, for the sake of game's balance, I understand. 

Buy it without hesitation and yes I'm a fanboy and yes i'm comfortable with that. But I was not born a fanboy, I became one.

Another fun expansion to the Dawn of War series. The campaign is a lot like Dark Crusade in that you have a campaign map of a planetary system to conquer. I did feel like Dark Crusade was better put together and more fun overall. There are new races with the Soul Sisters and the Dark Eldar. I did my playthrough as the Soul Sisters whose infantry is weak overall. I think they're pretty comparable to the Guardsmen. As far as gameplay all the games in the series are pretty fun although some races are more fun than others. The Original has the best story, Winter Assault has a good story as well (but frustrating missions), Dark Crusade was the most fun overall, and Soulstorm is a good addition with more maps, gameplay, and additional races.

The storyline is similar to Dark Crusade. It's expanded to cover an entire system called Kaurava System. Each faction has their own ending, and the only way to get there is to defeat all other factions. While I don't mind the story bits that the campaign has to offer, I don't think the RTS genre is for me. I do recommend this game to those that enjoy the gameplay that the genre has to offer, or if they want to see, and read the story bits that the game has to offer.

The finest of the Dawn of War series. Beyond this title, the creators eithor took too small or large a view of the Warhammer 40k Battlefield. Smaller detachments, like in DoW2 is a concept best suited for games like Mechanicus, Necromunda (if it ever releases), and Mordheim. the Epic scale Titans of DoW3 should have had the game focused on them, as we have never had a REAL Epic Scale WH40k game.. not ground based at least.

Having played all of the other Dawn of War expansions, this one certainly seems to be the weakest.  Don't get me wrong, it's still a load of fun, but when compared to the other installments in the series, this one feels a bit phoned in.  

If you've ever played Dark Crusade, it's very much like that.  But, in case you haven't, in Soulstorm you choose one of nine factions to lead to victory over the Kaurava system.  The system is divided into territories spanned across 4 planets and 3 moons.  Each faction starts controlling a certain number of territories, whereas the player starts with only a single territory.  Each faction must then battle it out for control of each territory in the system.  You defeat other factions by conquering their primary territory, known as their stronghold.  

In Dark Crusade the campaign played out in much the same fashion, but over a single planet rather than a system.  Furthermore, the backstory for the planet and each of the individual territories felt much more fleshed out in Dark Crusade.  The reasoning for the presence of each faction was better explained and the entire game just seemd to have more personality.

Aside from this, Soulstorm is really just more of the same.  And that's great if you're a Dawn of War fan.  It's great to finally see the Adepta Sororitas (Sisters of Battle) added to the game and the gameplay works just as well as it ever has.

Ultimately, I would recommend this game but only if you enjoyed the other Dawn of War installments.  If this is your first introduction to the Dawn of War Series, I would strongly recommend playing the other games first.

This was my introduction to the Warhammer Universe and it certainly did its job because now I am hooked on it. I have had this game for a few years and have sinked hundreds of hours into it. One of the best RTS experiences I've ever had. I love the basebuilding mechanics and the scale of the armies make battles feel absolutely massive. The game also has one of the most unique campaigns I've ever played, allowing you to play as any of the 9 races you want and conquer multiple planets one territory at a time while you and your enemies' armies grow stronger after every battle. The replay value is phenominal with dozens of maps to play on and different strategies for each faction. Multiplayer is great too and you can play as teams or free for all. The A.I. difficulty can range anywhere from complete trash to downright cheating, though. I recommend getting some mods for the game once you've gotten used to it because there are many that add news maps, units, and factions.

I consider this to be one of the if not the best RTS of all time. Each faction has a vastly different play style from one another with each set of units accomplishing different goals with their generally unique abilities or powers. The freedom this game offers is in my opinion its main selling points, other RTS games are so limiting with squad and army sizes but in DOW you can easily have an army of 50+ soldiers not even a quarter of the way through the match. Its an incredible 40k game and makes up for its bugs and age of graphics with entertaining and chaotic battles. If this game was ever remastered it would be the best selling RTS of all time.

The OG Dawn of War. Do yourself a favor & pick this up when they put the Master collection on sale for like... $8. But, it's worth it even if you don't want to wait for a sale. You'll want to have all of them so you can play with all the races in game.

I suggest taking it to the next level though with the Ultimate Apocalypse mod + accompanying additional map packs that got "Apocalyzed" (their personal edit to various maps to actually allow you to zoom all the way out like you're naturally used to doing in modern RTS's). Having played nearly 2k hours worth, I truly feel this is the way its meant to be played. It adds so much onto the experience &, personally, I find the AI remains a satisfying challenge on the hardest difficulties. Best of all, it's pretty authentic to lore (as far as it can while also maintaining some semblance of balance).

Without the mod, it's still a great game, but it's a product of its time. Graphically, it hasn't aged all that well, but the most frustrating thing will be how close the camera is locked in. Maybe it's just that frustrating for me because Ultimate Apocalypse spoiled me by fixing the camera, but it makes a HUGE difference.

The campaigns were a pleasant enough experience. Nothing too spectacular here, but it gets the job done. Skirmish mode is the bread & butter of this game though.

Great, well made RTS, that even today has a huge army of followers that enjoy themself in grimdark world of 41st millennia: some playing mods or relaxing 3-3/4-4, some challenging 1-1/2-2 in vanilla game. 

Gameplay is based on squad system instead of single unit (like in starcraft). What this means to an ordinary RTS player is that if you are not very gifted in terms of APM but can make quick decisions on fast-changing RTS battlefield then you have better chances in squad system RTS, then in more challenging single unit RTS, where you need to micro more precisely and you have much more subjects to control.

Story. Well, to be honest, this game is for infinite hours of skirmish battles and not for campaign. Dark Crusade delivers much better campaign in every way. In Soulstorm we don't have in-vox commanders' brawls during stronghold mission, we don't have our buildings in defense missions and now we have Megaman style strongholds instead of neutral territory with unique tasks. Combined with having to destroy every enemy building rather than just the HQ (like in Dark Crusade), it drags on to the point of tedium.

All in all, Soulstorm is satisfying RTS game for a countless hours of multiplayer skirmish battles. Although moving from the first Dawn of War game, that even has place in cybersport hall of glory as it was one of the WCG 2005 official games, adding more and more races made some of the match-ups questionably balanced (however, the vast majority of players still blame the eldars and fail to notice imbalance in other match-ups).

The game is terrible, the gameplay has been massively downgraded from dark crusade in several ways:
-Areas you control no longer save their buildings following a capture or attack, forcing you to either pay req for  forward structures or forcing you build a new base from scratch.
-The game is overall much slower, earning req and capturing territory takes a much longer amount of time (Mainly due to the victory condition being changed from destroying the HQ to destroying all enemy structures.
-Many parts of the story are nonsense (See Boreal's speech and Imperial guard's baneblade miss-shipment, as well as the simple fact space travel is supposed to be impossible during a warpstorm yet some of the stronghold abilities work off ship travel)

Now the question then stands: Why a positive review?

Because Soulstorm is home to the biggest mod of Dawn of war: Ultimate Apocalypse
Ultimate Apocalypse is to Dawn of war as Brutal doom is to the original doom, except much bigger in scale, adding two new factions to play with (Inquisition and Tyranids) as well as increasing the amount of units to play with by a thousand fold, as well as adding titan scale units and expensive super weapons.

To summarize: If you know how to mod, then I would highly recommend this game. If you don't like modding, then I would give this game a pass unless you are only planning to play multiplayer.

Highly addictive RTS game from the good old days. Think along the lines of Age of Empires, Warcraft, Starcraft and such but place it in the brutal gothic future that is Warhammer 40k. Large range of factions and playstyles for each, brute force into anything with Orkz, be clever with the ying/yang Eldar and Dark Eldar, throw a ton of bodies at the opposition with the Imperial Guard, serve the God-Emperor as the Angels of Death (Spaaaaceeeeh Maaaaarineeeees) or his fan girls, unleash eternal devotion to the Dark Gods of Chaos, command an undying legion of cyber-zombies.... or be a space weeb with the Tau (what is 'melee'?). Modding community has given us Ultimate Apocalypse, adding even more to each faction along with some new factions all together (nomnom Tyranids, Daemons of Chaos and the Inquisition's Daemon Hunters). Settings are a tad old and it's unlikely to have the perfect setup you want but it'll run on taters (yes including Ultimate Apocalypse). The Narrator for the campaign is a god, I could fall asleep to that voice. Worth the full price... for those money goblins they do have bundle sales for the entire Dawn of War series every odd monthly sale.

(Note that this review is for single player only)

It's all right?

Positives: Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle seem cool, although they each have a largish number of new mechanics and no real solid explainers for those mechanics. Air units are cool, but some of them are crazy OP, and the AI does not handle them well. They also don't 100% make sense, since they just hover...not how airplanes work IRL, but it's ok I guess.

Negatives: Shows its age. Every once in a while you see an asset or texture that has, like, 6 pixels (and I was playing at 1440p!). There's also just in general a lot of OpenGL fuckery going on that you can see super well given the passage of time. The campaign is mechanically the same as the one from Dark Crusade, so just because it's a solar system rather than a planet don't go expecting anything fancier. They also took out a few cool things like when you conquer a region, you get to keep the buildings you built, but then they added a few things like webway gates and arguably better powers, so that feels like a wash. There are three campaign difficulties. Easy is where you can probably speedrun the campaign in two hours or some shit. Normal is where you have to put in a modicum of effort, but you're never really in danger of losing a single battle. Hard is where every battle you get curbstomped by an AI that starts with more stuff than you could build in the first fifteen minutes. There is no middle ground.

I want to note quickly that the skirmish AI seems to have gotten worse since Dark Crusade (the campaign AI is bad too, but then it was bad to begin with). I played a game against the Dark Eldar where they built two combat units ever. I went to their base to destroy it, and it had all of the builders and all of the plasma generators, but nothing else. Why? No goddamn clue. The AI also loves spamming heroes and non-reinforced units, but I think in 6 or 7 games I only saw like 5 reinforced units (this is playing at campaign normal, because I don't like getting curbstomped). I have no idea why it makes such poor decisions.

Using Steam Play/Proton on Linux, I had it crash twice in 5 hours, so just FYI if you're on Linux. It didn't crash in battles, but it did crash in the campaign interface, so stability will hurt you. No idea if that's a game thing or a Proton thing, but just throwing it out there.

This game is a little bit of a buggy mess, the engine it was built in wasn't designed for the air vehicles it adds, and the campaigns cut a lot of corners but dammit I love it.
Singleplayer: If you are fine with an AI that cheats and cheats blatantly but is very very stupid, you might like the single player experience of this game. The harder campaign missions pit you against multiple AI. These missions will tend to revolve around whether or not you can rush one of them and kill them before they can get started, it leads to very fast paced game play which is why I like it so much. You also get to buy starting units and buildings which let you get into the fight even faster. Persistent bases from Dark crusades are gone which is good for the overall balance of the campaign as it gives meaning to purchasing defenses and stops you from roflstomping the ai or building defenses for an hour. One glaring flaw in the AI is that on the world map they rarely leave their starting worlds meaning that after you conquer your own starting planet their is nothing stopping you from skipping turns repeatedly to save up resources. I suggest you try to win in as few turns as possible to challenge yourself and improve the experience.
Multiplayer: I have played one multiplayer game and it was awful. These older dawn of wars have several bad mechanics that make the game play very frustrating. A few examples: 
1) Vehicles force infantry to get out of the way whenever they move this includes vehicles that 'certain' races have which can jump jet across the map, thereby providing an invisible barrier you cannot cross for several seconds and tangling up your infantry in a traffic jam while they get shot. 
2) Melee units can't do any consistent damage as a competent player can just tell his units to run away. Even if your units start swinging if a unit moves too far away before the attack animations finish they don't take any damage. Effectively melee units are worthless except to force enemies to move instead of shoot.
3) The game play tends to be very vehicle focused due to several other mechanics that I won't get into.
4) The game is very clearly unbalanced, this is inevitable with an asymmetric game, but the balance could be a lot better than it is. As it stands, Eldar is the most over powered race I've ever seen in an RTS (except for maybe Yuri from C&C:RA2), having several abilities which give them superb mobility for few or no downsides. 
TL;DR if you are a masochist that likes unfair older RTSes, and can put up with occasionally clunky controls. This is a good game for you.
Oh yeah and there is a pretty cool mod called Ultimate Apocalypse that makes the game about 10 times bigger, crashes a lot though.

This game will suck sometimes. Sometimes the AI will be rude, and stomp you so early. Sometimes your friends will rush you, and make the game no fun at all. But then other times, you'll have a fight you don't think you can win. The odds are against you, seeming insurmountable. Then, you'll catch a break. A vulnerability in the enemy will make itself apparent, and if you grab it, exploit it, and turn it to your advantage, you can take the upper hand. There is nothing as satisfying as starting the round as the underdog, beaten up on by your opponent, and ending it by smashing those who hurt you to teeny tiny little bits.

Lesson being: Losing will set you free. Each loss is just another reason to win. Another strategy gained from your enemy. Another weapon in your arsenal in the next fight. And, eventually, that next fight will come that you can use all of those losses to turn into a win.

This game adds Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle to the races from Dark Crusade.  Can't speak to Dark Eldar--the Sisters of Battle have a "Faith" mechanic that takes some getting used to, but they're fun.  They also add flying units to everything, but those are mostly pointless.  The campaign feels mostly faceless and storyless--there's no special challenge maps like "find the servitors" or "defeat only with the units you have" like there were in Dark Crusade, and maps don't keep the buildings from your last playthrough, which makes defenses more interesting, but also ruins any sort of sense that you're fighting over genuine encampments.  It feels like a long stretch of skirmish maps and not much more.  There's not even any unique dialogue between races like there is in Dark Crusade.  Ultimately it feels less like an actual narrative and more just a montage of interchangeable RTS maps.

I recently went back to Soulstorm for the challenge of beating the campaign on the hardest difficult. I played as the SM becaue they are generally the most balanced and versatile race. Spent a little bit of time in the skirmish mode with the other races but not a whole lot. Cant speak on the multiplayer as i did not go back to it this time. Had an all round great experience revisiting the series.

Some things have not aged well though. The pathfinding can be a bit frustrating sometimes. The campaign can get a bit repetitive when you are having to defend a province for 4 or 5 turns in a row. This means having to play the same skirmish map repeatedly until capturing all the provinces around or wiping out the other races on that planet. It is generally agreed that the campaign in Dark Crusade more engaging and is considered the highlight of the series. I would have to agree with this.

The voice acting is stellar and really makes you feel like your in the 40k universe! Even though a lot of the lines get repeated throughout battle many times is did not bother me at all. The races are very diverse and there is plenty of variety for different play styles. There is loads of replay value in learning and becoming proficient in all the races. The character models and animations still look good today and there are mods available for improving the graphics. There is a mod called turbo mode that enables widescreen and the ability to zoom out which are both excellent additions that I would recommend. There is also of course the Ultimate Apocalypse mod as well which is massive and adds a ton of units.

Overall the 50+ hours i spent revisiting Soulstorm was well spent and I would still recommend this game in 2020 to both new and returning players alike. "For the Emperor!"

Ah Soulstorm, I remember when we were all raising hell about this game due to all the mistakes and removed features.  Then DOW II came out and everyone was like....lets play some Soulstorm.  I recommend picking this up if your a fan of the series or even just an RTS fan.  A few things on this game for the few out there that may not know already.  The short version of a very long story is that the team working on this game basically got between sixty or seventy percent complete and then were flat told great work guys but after this is done you are all fired.  Due to that happening there are quite a few mistakes in the game that persist to this day from things as large as things that will crash HQ battles if you get a little to creative or clever (like destroying the Tau guidance beacons before you get your base sent in so that you are not racing a timer) to little things like Carron's Daemonic Ascension having Eliphas' name in it.  For those of you like me who are not millenials this game came out right when gaming as a whole was starting to shift to the millenial mindset so where Dark Crusade was based on the harder you work the better your game went and patience, Soulstorm is all based on "I can beat someone in ten seconds better than you can."  It is all rush tactics which is why your base structures no longer stay when built during battle and honor guard prices absolutely skyrocketed.  Small changes were made completely based upon rush tactics to make things more challenging for rushing as well such as a province getting two bases now at a strength of five instead of six and since bases don't stay now enemy attack strength in defensive battles is based upon the general and his/her honor guard instead of the strength of the province he/she is attacking from.  Overall this is what I would say to answer most of the common questions.
Is Soulstorm worth buying? Yes
Is it as good as Dark Crusade? No
How are the two races that were added? Worthless.  The Dark Eldar have crap morale, as in the elite of elites in the army topping out at 300 and the vehicles are made of paper.  Yes they can be very powerful in the hands of a practiced player but so can any faction.  The Sisters of Battle are absolutely terrible if you play multiplayer millenial style (rush rush rush look I can beat you in three seconds better than you can beat me in three seconds) and grossly overpowered OG style (No rush timers, map divide restrictions, true skill based matches).  
Should I go pass this game in the franchise? No, actually hell no.  DOW II and on are trash games that are way overpriced for what you get, especially Retribution and the developers have already pulled the Blizzard and abandoned the game with public apologies completely blaming listening to what fans of a younger age wanted.  Blizzard at least had the balls to outright blame millenials DOW III did as well but in a hint hint way.  Multiplayer is still strong in Soulstorm and back whereas it is basically dead on DOW II and furthur outside of a very small, extremely dedicated fan base.  That is pretty much it, my score 7/10.

The first Dawn of War brought RTS new elements such as cover, squads, morale, sync kills, everyone was amazed. Winter Assault brought new factions and 2 new campaigns. Dark Crusade gave Dawn of War a new flavour with a meta map playing like Risk but maps are fought in RTS. Soulstorm's only new features are 2 new factions, flying vehicles, a new campaign, and retweaked gameplay elements.

There are 7 playable factions in Dark Crusade, Soulstorm brings in 2 new factions; Dark Eldar and Sisters of Battle. All factions have their own advantages, disadvantages, significant playstyles, and starting abilities. Upon defeating an enemy stronghold, your playing faction will gain said defeated enemy ability in the single player campaign.

Chaos
Advantages: Diverse Infantry, Strong morale, chaos magic, morale depleating abilities.
Disadvantages: Expensive buildings, some infantry and vehicles are more expensive.
Significant Playstyle: Diverse infantry allows for very versatile playstyle.
Starting Ability: Collect all resources from every territory regardless of connection.

Dark Eldar
Advantages: Fast moving infantry and vehicles, invisiblity, buildings self build, anti morale attacks, regain morale abilities.
Disadvantages: Buildings take up plenty of space, infantry and vehicles are relatively weak.
Significant Playstyle: Hit and run tactics meaning strike key locations rather than mass infantry/vehicle assaults. 3rd resource; souls for powerful abilities that regain morale, damage enemy morale, or cause widespread damage.
Starting Ability:Travel through any webway gates in meta map.

Craftworld Eldar
Advantages: Fast movement speed, teleport via webway gates, or ability, invisibility, thin narrow buildings that take up less space, inexpensive infantry and buildings. 
Disadvantages: Weak infantry and buildings.
Significant Playstyle: Hit and run tactics, fast movement speed and high damaging weapons encourage great use of playstyle.
Starting Ability: travel up to 3 captured territories per turn on meta map.

Imperial Guard
Advantages:Useful attatchable commanders, inexpensive infantry, fast renforcements, use of building as bunkers, arguably best and most versatile vehicles, and best relic unit; The Baneblade.
Disadvantages: Weakest infantry units, weakest morale, low hardcapped elite units not effective without commanders, large numbers, or vehicle support.[b] *BLAM!*  CALLING IMPERIAL GUARD WEAK IS HERESY! [/b]
Significant Playstyle: Mass infantry, attrition assaults, vehicles are a staple.
Starting Ability: Anything bought with meta map requistion is cheaper.

Necrons
Advantages: Most durable Infantry, strong morale, fallen units may be revived, some units can teleport, commander has special abilities to mix and match, some units are free.
Disadvantages: Only builder units can capture strategic points, slowest moving faction, slowest production and renforcements, vehicles are weak and difficult if improperly used.
Significant playstyle: Only one resource is used, capturing points reduced production time, durability and good morale is suited for attrition.
Starting Ability: some garrison and honour guard can be recovered

Orks
Advantages: Fast production and unit renforcement, good durability and morale, cheap infantry, strong melee, most buildings have machine gun emplacements.
DIsadvantages: Least accurate ranged units, unintelligent units won't fight unless ordered, must build plenty of banners,[strike] Relic unit; the Squiggoth is not very manuvarable, weak againt most relic units, and painful to use [/strike] [b] WUT ARE YA TALKIN' BOUT HUMIE GIT? DA SQUIGGOTH IS A MIGHTY BEAST DAT WILL KRUMP ALL YA HUMIES, POINTY EARS, SPIKY BOYS, AND WUT ELSE. NOW LEAVE, YOU AIN'T GUD ENUFF FOR OUR LIST! 
SIGNIFIKANT PLAYSTYLE: WE BUILD WAAAGH BANNERS FOR MORE BOYZ, WHEN WE GETS MORE BOYS, WE GET DA NOBS FOR A STRONGA ATTAKK AND DAKKA, AND DEN WE FLOODS DA HUMIES, ELDAR, METAL BOYS, TAU, WITH DA GREEN TIDE! WAAAAAAGGGGHHH!!!!
STARTIN' ABILITY: WHEN WE CAPCHUR A PIECE OF LAND, OUR GROTZ AND BOYZ  WILL SLOWLY COME TO GUARD DAT LAND AND DEFEND! [/b]

Sisters of Battle
Advantages: Mix between SM and IG; cheap infantry, fast reinforcement, good durability and morale. Versatile and powerful vehicles.
Disadvantages: Relic unit; Living Saint is not powerful in damage, use more as support unit. Commanders have mediocre health but make up with faith abilities.
Significant Playstyle: Flamers and meltas are a staple, morale destroyer with flamers, melee units are powerful, 3rd resource is faith; generated by buildings and some units, to use as abilities offensively, defensively, or support.
Starting Ability: Forward base, set up a base before attacking a territory.

Space Marines
Advantages: Diverse and Versatile weaponry to properly counter your opponent, strong durability and morale.
Disadvantages: Expensive infantry, vehicles, and buildings.
Significant Playstyle: Versatile and customizable squads and vehicles allow for versatile gameplay. Attach commanders to squads for full effectiveness.
Starting Ability: Deep strike; get additional units to start with in a battle.

Tau
Advantages: Best range in the game (obviously), kroots, vespids auxilleries to make up for melee, invisiblity, awesome gunships, and powerful battlesuits.
Disadvantages: Worst melee in the game(even more obviouse) No turret/landmines.
Significant Playstyle: Shoot at a distance, elite tier units can either be a more battlesuits and an elite gunship, or better kroot units and upgrades.
Starting Ability: Moon Cannon that weakens defenses.


The story in Soulstorm is almost a carbon copy of Dark Crusade, we have an array of factions flooding to a system with the intension of getting rid of all other factions. The Imperium of Man is at each others' throats again (even the inquisition). The story has some lore contradicting themes such as the 3 factions of the imperium using xenos technology; webway and tau moon cannon, craftworld eldar not tricking enemies to fight eachother, sister of battle fighting aliens and demons despite being the armed wing of witch hunters etc.

Comparing Dark Crusade, there were some major downgrades, character dialogue interactions during stronghold assaults are gone, some voice actors not returning, 4 planets make meta map awkward, and wargear choices are very goofy looking even by 40K standards such as Vance Stubbs holding the plasma gun sideways like a gangster.

Despite Soulstorm being arguably the least impressive of the 4 first Dawn of War games, what made Soulstorm memorable were the memes it spawned; yes the voice acting was bad, but it was so bad  it's good, Indrick Boreale has a very laughable accent that made him speak weird. "Batul Brothas!" (Battle Brothers!), "Spehss Mahrens" (Space Marines), "Blud Rehvens" (Blood Ravens), "Empra" (Emporer), "Steel Rehn" (Steel Rain). Not to mention being the baldest and fewlish man in the imperium. Firaeveus Carron screaming "METAL BAWKSES!" when he sees Rhino Transports. Vance "Motherf***ing Stubbs being a fan favorite in Soulstorm because he is the only likable characters other than Gorgutz, and being hailed as the manliest Imperial Guard member 2nd to Sly Marbo, and also sending away 100 baneblades out.

Modders have created mods such as Ultimate Apocalypse for Soulstorm featuring more units, more factions, and bigger battles to fight.

[spoiler]Despite fans wanting the canonical victor to be Imperial Guard, Orks turned out to be victor according to Dawn of War 3- [b] WE'Z BAKK HUMIE, NOW SKRAM YA GROT LUVIN' GIT!!! BEEKUZE WE'Z DA KANON VIKTA OF DA GAME, AND NOT IN DARK KRUSADE, OUR BIG BOSS GURGUTZ TOOK DA NAMES DAEMONKILLA (chaos), GHOSTKILLA (Craftworld Eldar), GUNSMASHA (Imperial Guard), DEATHKILLA (Necrons), BLOODSPILLA (Blood Ravens Space Marines), RAGESCREAMA (Tau), NOT TO MENSHUN PAINKILLA (Dark Eldar), AND BITCHSLAPPA (Sisters of Battle). [/b] [/spoiler]

Play the first 3 Dawn of War games first before playing Soulstorm.

Once again i started a DoW game by picking up a cool-looking faction, which somewhat bored me with the gameplay. My first choice was Adepta Sororitas and while they turned out to be as weak as ranged factions, their playstyle is still mimics that of Adeptus Astartes. For throwaway maps it wasn‚Äôt that big a deal, but on story-missions sometimes it was hard. Worst one was the mission against Astra Militarum. When you and the AI start on equal you can suppress their expansion by the virtue of having human player powers. But their home-base starts already at maximum strength and once scripts allow it, they harass you with attrition. I lost or abandoned the fight several times, until I noticed why exactly my dumb experimental tactic i used on some plain maps has worked before. Adepta Sororitas Rhino transport has a ton of HP, costs about nothing and while it shoots like ork towers ‚Äî a lot of animation, but only one low damage bullet once in a while, and their unit cap is ridiculous. I just flooded the map with stupid transports and overwhelmed any Baneblade thrown at me. From that moment i employed this dumb and boring but effective tactic every time I got in trouble. While aesthetically interesting the rest of Adepta Sororitas units are pretty weak and boring. The new Dark Eldar are cool, pretty effective and well balanced. Necrons this time started to talk in cutscenes, which is stupid, but whatever.

The rest of the game is exactly the same as Dark Crusade. Padding skirmish maps, powerful bonus squads, pretty upgrades for the leader, cool home-base fights with cutscenes and different goals, and three (!) Imperium factions at war with each other and with not much explanation. There are new flying units for everyone, and a new titan for Necrons. But the flyers at this scale are pretty meaningless and Deceiver is really meh. Global map looks like several planets and that‚Äôs cool.

Somewhere in the middle of my complete walkthrough i‚Äôve installed an FoV mod, and after that it‚Äôs impossible to go back. The game was never released on consoles, and even if we consider the possible reasoning that 2004‚Äôs average hardware was not being able to process such tiny amount of fully 3D units at minimum settings, this expansion was released in 2008. Nothing prevented the devs from unlocking the camera, the mod looks like it wasn‚Äôt that hard to create. After tasting proper FoV, unmoded version feels painfully claustrophobic and unstrategic. You can‚Äôt make adequate decisions, when you lack information, and the game‚Äôs friendly AI is pretty pathetic on its own.

For anyone who likes Dark Crusade there‚Äôs no reason to not like this serving of more of the same.

40k RTS done right, and in my opinion the last good Dawn of War game that they released. This game is the classic RTS base builder. Build up your base, you army and duke it out. Like Star Craft or Halo Wars. While there are Characters such as Chapter masters, Archons, etc. the most effective way to beat the game is to play to your army's strength ex: Space marines, build Space marines and Dreads, IG hunker down with infantry and kill everything with your tanks. Chaos, build up Space marines and Demons with defllers. This game captures the 40k table top in such a way that people still play to this day. It isn't graphic intensive, can be played offline the campaign is great you have to kill every other army wiping them out or driving them out of the solar system you're trying to take in the name of your faction you have chosen. The factions in this game consist of Space Marines, Chaos, Imperial Guard, Sisters of Battle, Orks, Tau, Necrons, Eldar, Dark Eldar. You can make your own color schemes so fan made armies can be made such as ANGRY MARINES and the pony marines (look them up xD) However in the campaign your stuck to set chapters for each army, Blood Ravens, Black Legion, Bloody Rose, etc. etc. the game plays like Rock paper scissors, each army has an answer for something another army has, even adding Planes into the mix. The battlefield awaits will you help the imperium and purge the xeno, kill the heretic, and slay the mutant or will become the imperium of mans down fall as you play Xenos or even the heretic astartes. Always remember in the 41st millennium THERE IS ONLY WAR.

Soulstorm was the last Dawn of War expansion, the only one not developed by Relic. It's widely considered the worst one for good reason.

Soulstorm introduces two new races, the Sisters of Battle and the Dark Eldar. Both races are okay on their own but don't feel as unique as the Necrons or the Imperial Guard from the prior expansions, and many fans would've preferred some of the more unique races to play as such as the Tyranids. Alongside that, Soulstorm also recycles the RISK style campaign from Dark Crusade. But they somehow made it worse by making the UI more cluttered and having significantly worse writing and voice acting. The campaign feels like busywork to go through as a result and you're better off just replaying Dark Crusade's.

So why is this recommended? Well, since Soulstorm was the last expansion it contains all of the skirmish maps and races from the prior games. Plus some new stuff. It was also modded the most, with several extremely impressive modifications made exclusively for it. Such as the famous Ultimate Apocalypse mod that significantly increases the size of the battles you undertake. There's even a mod that allows you to play the original campaign and Winter Assault, in Soulstorm with its new units. As a result its easily the most "complete" one to just jump into skirmish or multiplayer in. It's an expansion that's largely only good due to the past work of Relic and not the new developers, and only benefits from being "the last expansion" and having so many mods for it. As a result it's recommended from me just for that reason. But as a stand-alone experience it's easily one of the worst 40k games.

The concluding expansion pack to the now classic Dawn of War 1 RTS game. 

Soulstorm is considered by many to be an inferior expansion to Dark Crusade due to it's recycled and overly lengthy campaign, the failure to bring Tyranids into the game and many gamebreaking exploits when the game was first released. 

Still, most of those issues are now fixed and Soulstorm is definitely the most balanced version of Dawn of War. Where Dark Crusade have both Necrons and Tau being very overpowered at every stage of the game and the cheaper teching costs allowed races such as Chaos Marines to fast tech to T3 and overwhelm opponents with elite units, Soulstorm has none of those issues and while the balance is not perfect, each race all have highlights.

With Dawn of War 2 being very different and 3 being a disaster, Soulstorm now stands as the most popular game in Dawn of War. Any fan of RTS should check it out.

I was playing a game awhile back with some friends (I was playing Chaos). The game got bugged after awhile, it was a very long game of Annihilation.

My most memorable moment from that game was sending two squads of berzerkers after some imperial guards and a chimera. Some of the guards jumped into the chimera and cornered themselves.  My berzerkers' voices got looped and kept screaming "BREAK THEIR BACKS! BREAK THEIR BACKS! BREAK THEIR BACKS!" their voices overlapping before cracking open the tank and killing everyone inside.

After the game, I told everyone what had happened with my berzerkers' voices and we started discussing how fucking scary that would be... Being stuck in a tank that can't escape and these giant armored men swinging massive axes that sound worse than chainsaws into the tank and GETTING THROUGH. Except, chain axes aren't all you hear, you just "BREAK THEIR BACKS!" getting louder and louder as new holes and gashes are chopped into the vehicle and you have nowhere to go. Your weapons do next to nothing against their armor as they fire random shots into the now massive holes on the tank.  The engine is long disabled, the crew is either dead or just as stuck as you are, the turret is dead because there's no power and the men scream "BREAK THEIR BACKS!" as everyone around you makes futile attempts to fight back before one of the armored men gets through the hatch, hacking at the nearest man then shooting several more before anyone can react.

Fucking terrifying.

Dawn of War : Soul Storm (Isha why?!)

The other expansions of Dawn of War were very good and well done, Soul Storm is absolute rubbish. I recommend the other expansions and avoid this one. The campaign tries to copy what Dark Crusade did, and just did it very poorly. The race balance is horrible, most of the game code is not optimized and lags horribly, especially when flamers are used, where the other expansions don't have this problem. Aircraft where slapped in so lackadaisically it borders on parody. The voice actors for these new units, factions, and characters are so bad, that mods for this game have better voice actors.

The only reason to get this expansion is for the excellent mods and the large player base, which this game has the largest player base of any of the Dawn of War games by a significant margin. Why people would play this expansion over Dark Crusade and/or DoW II and its expansions or even DoW III is beyond what even the seers can devine.

If you're from Youtube because of Ultimate Apocalypse, then what the fuck are you doing looking at reviews, BUY IT ALREADY! 

But if you're looking for an actual review... Here goes!

Pros:

Larger battles compared to DoW II and DoW III
Awesome modding support
Much more replay ability

Cons:

Old graphics
Buggy and prone to crashing
Modding is a must to make the game really enjoyable

More detail...

Compared to Dawn of War II and III, this is a bloody masterpiece!

With the larger maps, army sizes, and less captain of a squad feeling, the game has an overall much better feel for the universe of 40k. The awesome battles than can be made between your favorite factions in 40k, and seeing Necrons, Eldar, Imperium, and Tau all on the same big map fighting for resources is just pure awesomeness. 

The mechanics are also much more simple, and learning each faction takes a game or two, and then you pretty much understand how they work. Each faction is very similar, so its mostly the few unique things like Tau battlesuits or Necron destroyers that make each faction really stand out. 

Sadly the real meat of the game is hidden under mods, but luckily it doesn't take long. The mods for this game are pretty extensive, and the most infamous of these being Ultimate Apocalypse making into Supreme Commander with 40k. 

Also the game is rather buggy, and in my 200+ of gameplay with mods, i've crashed over 15 times being a mixture of pushing the engine too hard, and just looking at the menu the wrong way. 

All in all the game is fantastic, and if you're a 40k fan wondering wether this is better than DoW II or DoW III, this game will beat it any day! But for the real fun, you will have to mod the game, but that's not very hard luckily.

A true classic RTS that, with its great simplicity, achieves far more than any Dawn of War title has since. 

The race customization with no profanity filter to be spotted aids in making each playable race more personal (and humorous) when playing with other folks. The gameplay is simple, fun, and does not induce and salt- matches can easily be created again once your previous one is ended. 

Each race is so different to play with, though similar in base building mechanics enough to be able to pick each up on the fly when you want to try something new. There are plenty of maps to choose from, and plenty of ways to go about winning. Remarkably, even defensive playstyles are feasible, though can end up in incredibly grueling and long affairs when played with other people! The massive squadrons from each army that engage make battles a great treat. You can feel the weight of the war when you choose to send out a large force to engage the enemy. Being able to play with bots and change difficulty settings along with which races you are pitting yourself against adds an extra dimension of fun whether you face off those bots with friends, or face off your friends and the bots both! Soulstorm is the best title in a great classic series; its simplicity and customization, no matter how simple that is too, makes this my favorite 40K title ever.

Though, I have to warn you, playing against Space Marines is a task on its own!

The original four Dawn of War games were pioneers in the RTS category because it was the first true example of being able to customize your squads in whatever way that you saw fit. It was because of that very reason, and the hard work and dedication from the Warhammer community, that one of the best and most in depth mods for almost any game on the market, Ultimate Apocalypse, was created. It was based off of the original Warhammer tabletop game's 'Apocalypse' rule set, and allowed for large scale battles without spending hundreds of dollars and hours assembling armies and painting models. It allows for a whole host of other mods that can be downloaded for free and is an absolute blast to play, even without the mods. All in all it is a top tier game and i highly recommend it to any WH40K fan or strategy game player looking for a challenge as well as a good time.

I'll be honest. This expansion could have been better. The development of this expansion was clearly rushed but I still found enjoyment in it. The extra factions were a great add on and the nerf of the necrons was pleasing. Though the campaign is harder than it was in dark crusade. Although they made it harder for no reason. Its understandable that adding more challenge would make it more fun. But when they make the hardest difficulty basically impossible for some of the weaker factions. Also the main story makes no sense. Someone who knows even a little bit about Warhammer 40k will understand the strangeness and oddity of the story. I know that most of these are complaints but all in all, it is an upgrade from Dark Crusade in many ways, except the story. Seriously, what the hell. My rating is a 7/10. It could have been better.

If you like a classic, Sci-Fi,  realtime strategy game on an epic scale, then this is the game for you. The 1st Dawn Of War games like this one are absolutely wonderful in that regard. The 2nd DOW games are excellent too, with excecptional graphics for the Warhammer40k universe especially, but does not compare to what you can do in terms of scale with Soulstorm like building bases, and massive powerful armies; not to mention the awesome mods out there that cover the 40k universe in more detail like special units & abilities that weren't in the base game. The 3rd DOW game unfortunately didn't go so well with us 40k nerds, and were actually playing more DOW 1&2 instead.

Also you can use whats called "Corsix Mod Studio" to easily change various parameters and unit functions in the game. Allowing to create a battle of your own making with the AI actually being a competent lab rat/ opponent if you do it right. Endless possibilities, endless entertainment. Enjoy.

When you get right down to it, Soulstorm is pretty much a carbon copy of Dark Crusade. The big additions to the Warhammer 40K family are, once again, two more factions and a nonlinear campaign based on a Risk-style turn-based tactical map. Here, the two new sides are the fanatically religious Sisters of Battle, a group of pissed-off space nuns who take Catholic guilt to a whole new level, and the sadistic Dark Eldar, who chow down on souls for fun. The Sisters are most notable for such downright spooky units as the Penitent Engine, which consists of a heretic strapped to the front of a crucifix bot loaded with flamethrowers, and a faith resource that juices what amounts to battlefield spells. The Dark Eldar are almost as memorable, due to a nifty slave-and-demon thing going on with regard to units, and a new soul-essence resource that powers enemy-blasting combat abilities. But even though these features give the factions plenty of personality--particularly the Sisters, whose Canoness leaders screech loony battle cries like "Witchcraft, heresy, and mutation!"--neither brings much new to the table when it comes to gameplay. If you've already developed solid playing styles for the Imperial Guard or the Orks, you don't have to make too many changes to be effective while fighting as the Sisters or the Dark Eldar.

I'll consider this review as a reccomendation for the whole original Dawn of War series, seeing as I've played them all.

Warhammer: Dawn of War is probably the best RTS I've played - not because it's the most balanced or the most mechanically masterful, but because it's the most fun. The W40k universe is amazing and Dawn of War lets you play all of the races and factions that are a part of it. This variety of playable races alone is a factor that makes it a fantastic RTS.

Dark Crusade is the best expansion and has the best campaign, but Soulstorm is the crest of the Dawn of War series and is the most complete game. It's also the one that lets you add the Ultimate Apocalypse Mod, which truly allows you to play the W40k universe to its absolute fullest.

https://www.moddb.com/mods/ultimate-apocalypse-mod
you're welcome

After 15 years of playing this series, I am qualified to judge it.

I vastly prefer the original DoW, WA or even DC to this installment. The two new races both feature magic, and it just doesn't fit well with the other races. It's unbalanced somehow.

The AI is atrocious. Units getting stuck in terrain, units not engaging in melee even when told to, units disobeying orders, units doing nothing.

The campaign has some of the worst grind I have ever seen. Each stronghold map is a gruelling, minimum 2-hour snoozefest with waves upon waves upon waves of enemies hurled at your forces. These missions are heavily scripted and are really terribly boring.

The flyer units fit neither the engine nor the theme of this game, they were a complete waste of time and developer resources.

I'm starting to think that there is an upper limit to the usefulness of various races. Sometimes, more really is less.

I wanted to like this game. But it has all of the problems of its predecessors and offers no original design or solutions.

For those who are wondering what "UA" is, it stands for "Ultimate Apocalypse". It's a mod whose main feature is adding an incredible host of units, abilities, buildings, and even fleshed out factions to make the game more accurate to the incredibly vast Warhammer 40k lore. The base game is generally unfinished and hardly worth a single playthrough, and if you desire to play for the base game only I'd recommend avoiding the campaign entirely and sticking with the multiplayer/skirmish mode. The game goes for dirt cheap on sale, and you get an incredibly ammount of gameplay for your money with the UA mod.

I spent most of my DoW1 time on the physical version of Dark Crusade, probably about 200 hours, and however much time I played it back in high school with friends. This really is a RTS masterpiece, and there are plenty of mods that keep it alive in this modern era (especially the camera mod, a must have). A few balance hiccups don't keep this game from getting an A+. Good for single player or multiplayer. It's a shame that it was wasted on the childish WH40k setting, with an even more childish fanbase. I swear, WH40k fanboys are worse than sonic fans with how rabid they are. Still, it's master class RTS, you'd be hard pressed to find better.

This is the definite Dawn of War experience. While Dark Crusade felt undercooked in almost every way, this game really delivers. Better graphics, better AI, great maps and an overall level of polish the previous expansion lacked. No idea why Dark Crusade gets so much praise, Soulstorm is where it‚Äôs at. It runs smoother and at max settings compared to the previous game, which would chug for no reason. There are two new races with interesting new mechanics thrown in and new airborne units for every race.  The skirmish mode is a boatload of fun and the best way to spend your time. Campaigns in Dawn of War always feel like a slog, it feels better to jump into the action straight away. The musical score is fantastic and the game looks a lot more vibrant and colorful compared to the previous entries. Ultimate Apocalypse finally adds Tyranids and so much content that you can play this game forever. Praise the Emperor!

Let's be real, you are only here to play Ultimate Apocalypse.

And that's good, great even, go ahead and have a blast, as this is probably the greatest 40k experience you can have outside of tabletop.

But if we gotta talk soulstorm, there are a few points to touch. Rebalancing is a big one, especially for the campaign. You no longer keep all your structures built when fighting in a region, so the game becomes less of a secure-and-hold slog, and more dynamic. Warp gate missions are a nice change of pace, and don't suffer from a lot of the faction imbalance of the special maps in Dark Crusade. The new factions are aight, not exactly my style but they are well made. Flying units are a thing now, instead of only skimmer/jump units. This is great, especially for mods (again, the real reason you are here).

All in all, it's a solid addition to the existing title, and it got all the community goodies. What's not to love?

To put it simply, the only reason to buy Dawn Of War - Soulstorm is to get the Ultimate Apocalypse mod. The UA mod turns an incredibly sub par expansion pack into one of the greatest RTS games of all time. The mod more than triples the amount of content in the game and improves almost everything already existing in the game. Without UA, the Soulstorm expansions is essentially just a worst version of the Dark Crusade expansion, but with it might be one of the greatest RTS games ever produced.

This review is from 2019 - as you're planning to look into this old game, you'd might be surprised how active the community is and why - more on that later.

Soulstorm added 2 new playable factions, the dark eldar and the Sisters of Battle "Sororitas", in addition to aircrafts for every faction, a new legendary unit and global, map wide spells for the new ones. All in all it was "okay", but a little of a disappointment, because the single player campaign wasn't as good as in the predecessor, repetitive and boring - at least for me.

That being said, the modding community stayed active. There is a big mod called the "apocalypse mod" (Link below) that is still to this year (2019) played like hell. The installation is a bitt fiddly, the stability a little off. But: and this is a big but - it reworks every faction and adds new ones. You get tons of tanks with the imperial army. You can select chapters with Space Marines, your god with Chaos, Plague Marines - oh and not to forget: Titans. Yes, Titans. That shoot nearly across the entire map. You can crank up your video resolution and zoom farer out. This thing is played more than Dawn of War 3 thanks to this mods. So please check it out.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1090354545
Enjoy.

Dawn of War - Soulstorm by itself is a decent expansion of the Warhammer 40k Dawn of War game, with new factions with a turn based campaign to play them in and a good amount of units added to each faction the new standalone content although not always up to standards is definitely worth the buy.
However what really makes this expansion worthwhile is the Ultimate Apocalypse mod available from moddb. Adding multiple new races, units and maps all on a scale not seen before on the standard game, ultimate apocalypse catches the feeling of insanity that the expansions tried so hard to achieve, pitting titans the size of a skyscraper against giant tau mechs is quite a spectacle.

The soul of the 40k franchise is spectacle. Grand battles on huge scales with maximum devastation and carnage. While some may prefer the sequel to this game, Dawn of War 2, for its complex and engaging tactical skrmishes, there is still a place in my heart for the large strategic scale of Dawn of War 1.

What makes Dawn of War as a game is the aggression in place of civilization building like other real time strategy games such as Age of Empires. There are no villagers in Dawn of War. Besides builders, one will be presented with a wide range of purely military units to use at their disposal. In place of building farms for workers primary resources are either from simple buildings that generate them passively or, more importantly, from capturing points around the map. Territory is a huge part of Dawn of War, and the aggression to take said territory is essential to staying relevant economically. Some territory points even confer special bonuses such as unlocking special "relic" units, making these critical to getting the upper hand over your opponent (who would also very much like that same point for his or her self.) This aggressive play makes the game much more exciting than many other RTS games.

Honestly a pretty solid RTS game. If you want a 40K RTS, then this is the one to get, as opposed to the second or third games.

Though this game may not be as great as the original or dark crusade. Soulstorm still manages to be a genuine dawn of war game at best. The gamplay is as fun as it was the previous games and it adds two new races to expand on the diversity of race choices. In terms of units in the game they added aircraft for every race. (Necrons have the attack scarabs being more the aircraft based unit but no new aircraft for them.) As nice as it is to have aircraft units, it ain't quite the overhaul of units I was expecting like soldiers, vehicles and hero units. The story feels a bit more flat than normal; though I'll play Soulstorm's story again over dawn of war retributions campaign. And the one character I've gotten to enjoy out of all the rest has got to be Indrick Boreale (insert your Boreale memes here). And lastly the soundtrack is still awesome to hear. 

Overall the game is still fun to play even if the story isn't as good as the last, but if you really want to amp up the fun to 20 I'd suggest downloading the mod Ultimate Apocalypse for soulstorm; trust me it's worth a try.


***Disclaimer this review is total subjective and my experiences in game will most likely be different from other people's. Don't be pressured to go into a game until you're sure that you want to try it yourself and see what you think, it's best to go into something with minimum expectations and see afterwards where your opinions place on the content.***

It is the 41st Millennium. For more than a hundred centuries the Emperor of Mankind has sat immobile on the Golden Throne of Earth. He is the master of mankind by the will of the gods and master of a million worlds by the might of His inexhaustible armies. He is a rotting carcass writhing invisibly with power from the Dark Age of Technology. He is the Carrion Lord of the vast Imperium of Man for whom a thousand souls are sacrificed every day so that He may never truly die.

Yet even in His deathless state, the Emperor continues His eternal vigilance. Mighty battlefleets cross the daemon-infested miasma of the Warp, the only route between distant stars, their way lit by the Astronomican, the psychic manifestation of the Emperor's will. Vast armies give battle in His name on uncounted worlds. Greatest amongst His soldiers are the Adeptus Astartes, the Space Marines, bio-engineered super-warriors. Their comrades in arms are legion: the Imperial Guard and countless planetary defence forces, the ever-vigilant Inquisition and the Tech-priests of the Adeptus Mechanicus to name only a few. But for all their multitudes, they are barely enough to hold off the ever-present threat to humanity from aliens, heretics, mutants -- and far, far worse.

To be a man in such times is to be one amongst untold billions. It is to live in the cruelest and most bloody regime imaginable. These are the tales of those times. Forget the power of technology and science, for so much has been forgotten, never to be relearned. Forget the promise of progress and understanding, for in the grim dark future there is only war. There is no peace amongst the stars, only an eternity of carnage and slaughter, and the laughter of thirsting gods.

This is the best Warhammer 40k game made to date.  It's not even a close comparison to its successors or predecessors. Not only do you feel the differences in the units and their individual strengths and weaknesses, the campaign map is addictive and incredibly fun.  If they would simply make a graphics update I would buy the game again.  Simply put, this is the right formula for a Warhammer 40k RTS.

Being constructively critical, if you wanted to make a 'better' game, just flesh the components on this game out a bit more.  Grow the campaign map, add a few more units, increases the number of units that can be used in the field, etc.  You might experiment with increasing building limits for making defensive fortifications or making using a unit more painful.  Just keep in mind, this game is FUN!!  I'm suprised Relic or SEGA haven't done a remake of this game.  It seems like a money-maker.

Okay so you hear a lot of people say that Soulstorm was not as good of a game as Dark Crusade - those people are completely correct and here's why. 

In Dark Crusade, there was no difficulty in which the game felt unreasonably grindy. You either get crushed, or you steadily capture objectives until you complete the map. In Soulstorm - the game has grind out the butt. It's entirely possible to play one of the base capture missions for a literal hour, on medium difficulty, and feel like you've gotten absolutely nowhere. No objectives captured, game not lost. 

So instead of having missions where the mission comes to a head and a satisfying conclusion, what you get is a huge big boring stalemate. Sure, the game is alright, but compared to Dark Crusade it's not as good for this reason.

This isn't as good as the Dawn of War games that came before it, nor the games that followed it. It's not bad, but it has troubles. Single-player isn't as smooth as Dark Crusade, with a confusing interface (I can hardly see the territories on the tiny planets, and they don't zoom).

I won't complain at length, but I'm not too thrilled.

Dawn of War: Soulstorm is the last expansion released for the original Dawn of War.
Settled in the grim, futuristic setting of the Warhammer 40k universe it features heavy violence, marginal humour (with the orcs) and a dark atmosphere.
The base building is as simple as ever, you start with your HQ and your builder unit and build various military building, towers on control points and energy generators to progress thorugh the tech-tree. Unlike other rts-games dow is entirely focused on small skirmish-fights with relatively small armies (compared to Total War e.g.).
I personally enjoyed my time with DoW: Soulstorm. The two new races: Adeptus Sororitas and the Dark Eldar are a welcome addition to the roster of races. Although I have to say the Sororitas feel awfully similar to the normal Space Marines. The support of the modding community via nexusmods gave the game the longevity for me. With the race-combiner-mod you can have like ten or more races added to the original roster of races which improves on variety of gameplay. 
I highly encourage to at least check out what the mod creators have to offer: There is really good stuff out there. 
Summa summarum:
Soulstorm is a very simplistic, combat oriented oldschool-rts with base building which is not nearly as balanced as StarCraft is but if you are looking for a casual rts-experience I highly encourage to get this gem. 

PS: The Campaign isn't all that great.
PPS: DoW II & DoW II: Chaos Rising have a way better campaign ;)

[h1]The girls invade Warhammer! ;)[/h1]

I really love this DLC for what it is: an expansion which introduces us new races to play with. And as before we're in for a treat because the [i]Sisters of Battle[/i] once again provide you with an environment that requires a complete overhaul of your combat strategies due to the specific nature of the new tech tree. For example; the battle starts with commanding units which are sent out to capture the first strategic points and they will be joined by the Sisterhood at a later time. You still use the regular "attach squad" options, but having these go solo at first?  It's something else.

I think the Sisterhood is an awesome addition to the flock, however...  I do occasionally wonder about some of the infantry and vehicles because it just looks weird at times and maybe slightly comical. Making me wonder how serious this faction is being treated. Something my girlfriend always brushes off as me being silly, this is actually her favorite faction to use when we sometimes play together.

But yeah... Missionaries who can capture strategic points and after doing so pray to the Emperor: "[i]Hail to the Emperor for giving us this point[/i]", it sounds really funny ;)  Exorcist units (a vehicle) which look like driving organs, only there's no music coming out of the massive pipes but a barrage of missiles that can lay waste to the heretics! It always makes me grin a bit when playing with the Sisters of Battle.

[h1]Not the best in the series though[/h1]

Unfortunately there are several problems which don't really help for our enjoyment. The sound engine seems to have had an overhaul and because of that the game sometimes misses those brutal (sound) effects which made some of the other titles stand out. That battlecry in the very first introduction movie? Goosebumps!

It also doesn't help that the tutorial session suddenly features a different narrator. That alone isn't really a problem, but it gets annoying if the tutorial itself skips over important aspects of the game and leaves the player to figure those out for themselves. For example: No where in the Sisters of Battle tutorial will it tell you that you can attach commanding units to your squads, which is actually a [i]crucial[/i] part of the units strategy. That's sloppy.

As for the campaign... the gameplay is basically the same as that of Dark Crusade; you need to capture land in order to become stronger and defeat your enemies. Within that sense it sometimes feels as if this is "more of the same". Definitely fun to have and play, but not as good as previous titles.

This is such a fun game! I loved playing LAN parties with other people. Want to master a race? Super easy to pick up and play. Want something new? Mods can add new races which sticks you in even more! Quite easy as well. Plus it's cheap, especially when it goes on sale.

One of the best RTS of all time. BUY THIS GAME! I love Dark Crusade and played it growing up at LAN parties. I still play it to this day. 
Soulstorm takes Dark Crusade and injects it with steroids. There are 2 new races to play. Instead of conquering one planet, you are on a quest to dominate an entire solar system. Necrons are still the best, IMO.  They did nerf them a tad by making you control more points in order to have faster production. I will do a run through with the other races as soon as total Necron domination is achieved.  It's a shame they destroyed this franchise (Warhammer II and III) by making it a complex RTS RPG. The simplicity of this game is what makes it so addicting. The characters are fantastic and so are the animations. The stories and voice acting are actually great!  Don't sleep on this game it still stands the test of time.
